revision.text:
{{Infobox criminal organization |name = Cartel de los Soles |image = File:General de Brigada (PNG).png |image_size = 100 |caption = The group's name comes from the "sun" insignia of Venezuelan generals. |founded = |founder = <!--or | founders = --> |named_after = |founding_location = |years_active = 1990s – present |territory = [[Venezuela]] |ethnicity = |membership = |leaders = |activities = [[Drug trafficking]], [[arms trafficking]], [[money laundering]] |allies = * {{flag|Venezuela}} *{{Flagicon image|Flag of the FARC-EP.svg}} [[FARC]]<ref name=CARTELsuns/> *[[Sinaloa Cartel]] |rivals = |notable_members = }}
The term '''''Cartel of the Suns''''' ({{lang-es|Cartel de los Soles}}) describes a [[Venezuela]]n organization allegedly headed by high-ranking members of the [[Armed Forces of Venezuela]] who are involved in international [[Illegal drug trade|drug trade]].<ref name=CARTELsuns>{{cite web|title=Cartel de los Soles|url=http://www.insightcrime.org/venezuela-organized-crime-news/cartel-de-los-soles-profile|website=InSightCrime|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> According to Héctor Landaeta, journalist and author of ''Chavismo, Narco-trafficking and the Military'', the phenomenon began when Colombian drugs began to enter into Venezuela from corrupt border units and the "rot moved its way up the ranks".<ref name=MHjan27>{{cite news|last1=Wyss|first1=Jim|title=Venezuela’s Maduro calls reports that Cabello faces drug charges ‘vulgar’|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article8232987.html|accessdate=1 February 2015|agency=Miami Herald|date=27 January 2015}}</ref>
==History== {{details|Illegal drug trade in Venezuela}}
Reports that members of the Venezuelan military<ref>http://revolucionemosanzoategui.blogspot.com/2007/04/el-general-ramn-guilln-dvila-i.html</ref> were involved in drug trafficking began in the 1990s, though it was limited to taking payments and ignoring drug traffickers.<ref name=CARTELsuns/> It was alleged that officers of Hugo Chávez's [[Revolutionary Bolivarian Movement-200]] that planned the [[1992 Venezuelan coup d'état attempts]] had created a group that participated in drug trafficking that was known as the "Cartel Bolivariano" or "''Bolivarian Cartel''".<ref name=CARTELsuns/> Following the 1992 coup attempts, ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' noted that Venezuelan officers may have sought to take over the government since there was "money to be made from corruption, particularly in drugs".<ref name="LA1992">{{cite news|last1=Freed|first1=Kenneth|last2=Long|first2=William R.|title=Regional Outlook Recession, Corruption Fuel Latin Coup Jitters the Region has made Enormous Progress Toward Democracy. but Decades of Military-Dominated History are Hard to Erase|work=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|issue=pp. 6|date=15 December 1992}}</ref> In 1993, the term "Cartel de los Soles" or "''Cartel of the Suns"'' was first used when allegations of two National Guard generals, who wore emblems that looked like suns on their uniforms, were investigated for drug trafficking crimes.<ref name=CARTELsuns/>
===Bolivarian government=== The "Cartel of the Suns" name returned in 2004 by reporter and city council member Mauro Marcano. Shortly before he was murdered, Marcano alleged that Alexis Maneiro, head of the National Guard and the [[National Directorate of Intelligence and Prevention Services|Dirección General de Inteligencia Militar]], was involved in drug trafficking.<ref name="CARTELsuns" />
According to ''[[Vice News]]'', the Venezuelan government under [[Hugo Chavez]] expanded corruption to "unprecedented levels" in an already corrupt military.<ref name=VICEdrugs/> Chavez gave military officials millions of dollars for social programs that allegedly disappeared, also giving legal immunity to drug trafficking officials to maintain power and loyalty.<ref name=VICEdrugs/> When Chavez ousted the United States [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] in 2005, Venezuela became a more attractive route for drug trade.<ref name=VICEdrugs/> According to Colombian [[Intelligence agency|intelligence]], an arrested drug vigilante stated that "senior figures in President Hugo Chavez's security forces to arrange drug shipments through Venezuela".<ref name=TELE2007>{{cite news|last1=McDermott|first1=Jeremy|title=Venezuela is key link for the drug smugglers|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1557941/Venezuela-is-key-link-for-the-drug-smugglers.html|accessdate=1 February 2015|agency=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=19 July 2007}}</ref> It has been alleged that the National Guard had worked with the [[FARC]] with drug trade.<ref name=EPsol>{{cite news|last=Mario Cárdenas|first=Hugo|title=FF.AA. venezolanas tienen cartel propio|url=http://historico.elpais.com.co/paisonline/notas/Julio232007/narco.html|accessdate=26 May 2014|newspaper=El Pais|date=23 July 2007}}</ref> British officials alleged that planes from Colombia would also be sheltered by Venezuelan Air Force bases.<ref name=TELE2007/>
==Incidents== In September 2013, an incident allegedly linked to the Cartel of the Suns and involving men from the Venezuelan National Guard who placed 31 suitcases containing 1.3 tons of [[cocaine]] on an Air France flight astonished [[Charles de Gaulle Airport]] authorities as it was the largest seizure of cocaine recorded in mainland [[France]].<ref name=VICEdrugs>{{cite news|last=al-Ameri|first=Alaa|title=Venezuela's Drug-Running Generals May Be Who Finally Ousts Maduro|url=https://news.vice.com/article/venezuelas-drug-running-generals-may-be-who-finally-ousts-maduro|accessdate=26 May 2014|newspaper=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice News]]|date=31 March 2014}}</ref><ref name="ELPAISdrugs">{{cite news|last=Meza|first=Alfredo|title=Corrupt military officials helping Venezuela drug trade flourish|url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2013/09/26/inenglish/1380217098_793793.html|accessdate=18 March 2014|newspaper=El Pais|date=26 September 2013}}</ref> On 15 February 2014, a commander for the Venezuelan National Guard was stopped while driving to [[Valencia, Carabobo|Valencia]] with his family and was arrested for having 554 kilos of cocaine in his possession.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sanchez|first=Nora|title=Detienen a comandante de la Milicia con cargamento de drogas|url=http://www.eluniversal.com/sucesos/140215/detienen-a-comandante-de-la-milicia-con-cargamento-de-drogas|accessdate=20 April 2014|newspaper=El Universal|date=15 February 2014}}</ref> On 11 November 2015, DEA agents arrested two relatives (an adopted son and a nephew) of Venezuelan president [[Nicolás Maduro]] while trying to move 800 kilograms of cocaine from Venezuela to the USA, a source from DEA stated unofficially that there is no way that the huge amount of cocaine that passes through Venezuela does it without high levels of corruption in the government.<ref>http://cnnespanol.cnn.com/2015/11/11/autoridades-de-ee-uu-detienen-a-dos-familiares-de-la-primera-dama-de-venezuela/</ref>
==Organization== There are groups within the branches of the Armed Forces of Venezuela such as the [[Venezuelan Army]], [[Venezuelan Navy]], [[Venezuelan Air Force]], and [[Venezuelan National Guard]]; from the lowest to the highest levels of personnel.<ref name=CARTELsuns/>
===Low-level personnel=== Allegedly, lower ranking National Guardsmen compete for positions at border checkpoints so they can be paid bribes for "illicit trade", though a large portion of bribes go to their superiors.<ref name=CGviolence>{{cite web|title=VIOLENCE AND POLITICS IN VENEZUELA|url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/latin-america/venezuela/38%20Violence%20and%20Politics%20in%20Venezuela.pdf|work=Report|publisher=International Crisis Group|accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref> Allegedly, the corrupt officials of the Cartel of the Suns traffic drugs from [[Colombia]] to Venezuela where they are shipped internationally.<ref>{{cite news|title='Every last gram of cocaine is soaked with innocent blood'|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland/top-stories/every-last-gram-of-cocaine-is-soaked-with-innocent-blood-1-746724|accessdate=26 May 2014|newspaper=The Scotsman|date=14 May 2007}}</ref>
===High-level officials===
==== Nicolás Maduro ==== President of Venezuela [[Nicolás Maduro]] has personally promoted individuals accused of drug trafficking to high positions of the Venezuelan government.<ref name=":02">{{Cite book|title=Venezuela: A Mafia State?|last=|first=|publisher=[[InSight Crime]]|year=2018|isbn=|location=[[Medellin, Colombia]]|pages=3-84}}</ref> In May 2018, he was said to have received drug trafficking profits from Diosdado Cabello.<ref name=":0" />
====Diosdado Cabello==== In January 2015, the former security chief of both Hugo Chavez and [[Diosdado Cabello]], [[Leamsy Salazar]], made accusations that Cabello was head of the Cartel of the Suns.<ref name=ENHjan2015>{{cite news|last1=Maria Delgado|first1=Antonio|title=Identifican a Diosdado Cabello como jefe del Cartel de los Soles|url=http://www.elnuevoherald.com/noticias/mundo/america-latina/venezuela-es/article8206548.html|accessdate=27 January 2015|agency=El Nuevo Herald|date=26 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=ABCjan2015>{{cite news|last1=Blasco|first1=Emili J.|title=El jefe de seguridad del número dos chavista deserta a EE.UU. y le acusa de narcotráfico|url=http://www.abc.es/internacional/20150127/abci-venezuela-cabello-eeuu-201501262129.html|accessdate=27 January 2015|agency=[[ABC (Spain)|ABC]]|date=27 January 2015}}</ref> Salazar was placed in [[witness protection]], fleeing to the United States with assistance of the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]]'s [[Drug Enforcement Administration#Special Operations Division|Special Operations Division]] after cooperating with the administration and providing possible details on Cabello's involvement with international drug trade.<ref name=ENHjan2015/> Salazar stated that he saw Cabello give orders on transporting tons of cocaine.<ref name=ABCjan2015/> The shipments of drugs were reportedly sent from the FARC in Colombia to the United States and Europe, with the possible assistance of Cuba.<ref name=ENHjan2015/><ref name=ABCjan2015/> The alleged international drug operation had possibly involved other senior members of Venezuela's government as well, such as [[Tarek El Aissami]] and [[José David Cabello]], Diosdado's brother.<ref name=ENHjan2015/><ref name=ABCjan2015/>
On 18 May 2018, the [[Office of Foreign Assets Control|Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC)]] of the [[United States Department of the Treasury]] placed sanctions in effect against Cabello, his wife, his brother and his "testaferro" Rafael Sarria. OFAC stated that Cabello and others used their power within the Bolivarian government "to personally profit from extortion, money laundering, and embezzlement", with Cabello allegedly directing drug trafficking activities with Vice President of Venezuela, [[Tareck El Aissami]] while dividing profits with President Nicolás Maduro. The Office also stated that Cabello would use public information to track wealth individuals who were potentially drug trafficking and steal their drugs and property in order to get rid of potential competition.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm0389|title=Treasury Targets Influential Former Venezuelan Official and His Corruption Network|last=|first=|date=18 May 2018|website=[[Office of Foreign Assets Control]]|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 May 2018}}</ref>
==== Tareck El Aissami ==== Tareck El Aissami was sanctioned by the US Treasury Department on 13 February 2017 under the [[Foreign Narcotics Kingpin Designation Act]]<nowiki/>after being accused of facilitating drug shipments from Venezuela to Mexico and the United States, freezing tens of millions of dollars of assets purportedly under El Aissami's control.<ref name=":03">{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/02/14/press-briefing-press-secretary-sean-spicer-2142017-12|title=Press Briefing by Press Secretary Sean Spicer, 2/14/2017, #12|date=14 February 2017|website=White House|language=en|accessdate=20 February 2017}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a95c0636-f247-11e6-8758-6876151821a6|title=US labels Venezuelan vice-president a drug kingpin|last=Lynch|first=|last2=Sevastopulo|date=14 February 2017|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-02-15|last3=Schipani}}</ref>
==== Néstor Reverol ==== Head of the [[Venezuelan National Guard|Bolivarian National Guard]], [[Néstor Reverol]], has been indicted by the United States government of assisting with drug trafficking in Venezuela. Reverol allegedly tipped off traffickers, cancelled investigations and released those involved in drug shipments.<ref name=":02" />
====Hugo Carvajal==== [[Hugo Carvajal]] is allegedly one of the leaders of the Cartel of the Suns.<ref name=LAtimesJUL2014>{{cite news|last1=Mogollon|first1=Mery|last2=Kraul|first2=Chris|title=Former Venezuelan intelligence chief arrested on U.S. drug charges|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/mexico-americas/la-fg-venezuela-intelligence-arrest-drug-20140724-story.html|accessdate=1 February 2015|agency=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=24 July 2014}}</ref> On July 22, 2014, Hugo Carvajal, former head of [[Dirección de Inteligencia Militar|Venezuelan military-intelligence]], was detained in [[Aruba]], despite having been admitted on a diplomatic passport and being named consul general to Aruba in January.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-28472222 |title=Aruba detains Venezuelan general on US drug trafficking list |publisher=BBC News |date=24 July 2014 |accessdate=26 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="nyt-arrest">{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/25/world/americas/former-venezuelan-intelligence-chief-arrested-in-aruba.html | title=Former Venezuelan Intelligence Chief Arrested in Aruba | publisher=New York Times | work=New York Times | date=24 July 2014 | accessdate=2 August 2014 | author=Neuman, William}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Kejal Vyas & Juan Forero |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/retired-venezuelan-general-hugo-carvajal-detained-on-u-s-petition-1406227366 |title=Retired Venezuelan General Hugo Carvajal Detained on U.S. Petition |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date=24 July 2014 |accessdate=30 July 2014}}</ref> The arrest was carried out following a formal request by the U.S. government, which accuses Carvajal of ties to drug trafficking and to the [[FARC]] guerrilla group.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/07/27/world/americas/aruba-us-venezuela-ex-general-arrested/ | title=Aruba releases Venezuelan ex-general wanted in U.S. | publisher=CNN | work=CNN | date=28 July 2014 | accessdate=2 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=treasury>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/hp1132.aspx |title=Treasury Targets Venezuelan Government Officials Supporting the FARC |publisher=U.S. Department of the Treasury |date=12 September 2008 |accessdate=30 July 2014}}</ref> On 27 July 2014, Carvajal was released after authorities decided he had [[diplomatic immunity]], but was also considered [[persona non grata]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2014/07/140728_razones_holanda_liberacion_carvajal_ac.shtml | title=Cómo explica Holanda la liberación del general venezolano Hugo Carvajal | publisher=BBC News | work=BBC Mundo | date=28 July 2014 | accessdate=2 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="wsj-immunity">{{cite web | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/netherlands-rules-venezuelan-detained-in-aruba-has-diplomatic-immunity-1406505987#livefyre-comment | title=Netherlands Says Venezuelan Detained in Aruba Has Immunity | work=Wall Street Journal | date=27 July 2014 | accessdate=2 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dw.de/aruba-frees-venezuelan-diplomat-wanted-in-us-on-drugs-charges/a-17812023 | title=Aruba frees Venezuelan diplomat wanted in US on drugs charges | publisher=Deutsche Welle | date=28 July 2014 | accessdate=2 August 2014}}</ref>
====Yazenky Lamas====
Yazenky Lamas, former pilot to [[List of First Ladies of Venezuela|First Lady]] [[Cilia Flores]], was extradited to the United States from Colombia, having allegedly provided [[Transponder (aeronautics)|air traffic codes]] to allow planes carrying [[cocaine]] to impersonate [[Commercial aviation|commercial flights]].<ref>{{cite news |publisher=[[Insight Crime]] |quote=Prosecutors allege that Lamas played a central role in organizing drug flights by obtaining air traffic codes that allowed the planes to pass themselves off as commercial flights, among them a flight that travelled from the Venezuela-Colombia border region to Honduras with 1.6 tons of cocaine in 2015, according to Semana. |title=Venezuela Pilot's Extradition Could Lead to Cartel of the Suns Revelations |date=June 28, 2017 |url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/venezuela-pilot-extradition-could-lead-cartel-suns-revelations}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |publisher=''[[The Miami Herald]]'' |quote=Capt. Yazenky Antonio Lamas Rondón, 36, who once worked as the pilot for First Lady Cilia Flores, was arrested last month in Colombia under a request by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), which has started extradition procedures. |title=Venezuela to Colombia: Don’t extradite accused narco to US |first=Antonio Maria |last=Delgado |date=July 6, 2016 |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article87979462.html}}</ref> Venezuela President Nicolás Maduro reportedly asked Colombian [[Ministry of National Defense (Colombia)|Defense Minister]] [[Luis Carlos Villegas Echeverri]] to reject the request for extradition.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.insightcrime.org/news-briefs/venezuela-trying-to-block-extradition-of-cartel-operative-report |first=Dave |last=Gagne |title=Venezuela Trying to Block Extradition of 'Cartel Operative': Report |publisher=[[Insight Crime]] |date=July 7, 2016 |quote=According to anonymous sources consulted by el Nuevo Herald, Maduro told Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos he needed a favor while the two heads of state were in Havana, Cuba at the end of June for the signing of a bilateral ceasefire agreement between the Colombian government and rebel group the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia - FARC). But it wasn't until the following week that Maduro allegedly communicated to Colombian Defense Minister Luis Carlos Villegas that he wanted the Colombian government to do "everything possible" to prevent the extradition of Venezuelan Capt. Yazenky Antonio Lamas Rondón to the United States.}}</ref> Lamas has been linked to hundreds of drug flights operated in Venezuela.<ref name=":02" />
==== Others ==== Other officials that are possibly involved with the Cartel of the Suns include:<ref name=":02" />{{columns-list|*Clíver Alcalá Cordones *[[Freddy Bernal]] *[[Jose David Cabello]] *[[Amílcar Figueroa]] *Bladimir Flores *Carlos Malpica Flores *Walter Gavidia Flores *Darry Fortoul Ochoa *Eliecer García Torrealba *Carlos Justiniano Núñez *Jesus Itriago *Ramón Madriz *Rodolfo McTurk *Edylberto Molina *Frank Morgado *Benny Palmeri-Bacchi *[[Rafael Ramírez (Venezuela)|Rafael Ramírez]] *[[Henry Rangel Silva]] *[[Ramon Rodriguez Chacin]] *Vasily Villarroel Ramírez *Rafael Villasana F.|colwidth=22em}}
==Allies== ===FARC=== {{main|Corruption in Venezuela#FARC}} In 2005, all branches of the [[National Bolivarian Armed Forces of Venezuela]] were given the duty to combat drug trafficking in Venezuela, granting data once held only by the Bolivarian National Guard to the army, navy and air force. Mildred Camero, former anti-drug official of the Chávez government, stated that this data created competition within the ranks of the military who fought to make deals with the FARC to actively partake in drug trafficking.<ref name=":02" />
Authorities in [[Colombia]] stated that through laptops they had seized on a raid against [[Raul Reyes]] in 2007, they found documents purporting to show that Hugo Chávez offered payments of as much as $300 million to the [[FARC]] "among other financial and political ties that date back years" and documents showing the FARC rebels sought Venezuelan assistance in acquiring surface-to-air missiles, alleging that Chavez met personally with FARC rebel leaders.<ref name="Padgett">{{cite news|last=Padgett|first=Tim|title=Chávez and the Cash-Filled Suitcase|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1838145,00.html|accessdate=28 March 2014|newspaper=TIME|date=3 September 2008}}</ref><ref name="FARCrafael">{{cite web|title=FARC files 'show ties to Chavez'|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/americas/2011/05/20115115856153893.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="USATODAYfarc">{{cite news|title=Colombia: Chavez funding FARC rebels|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-03-02-venezuelacolombia_N.htm?csp=34|accessdate=21 April 2014|newspaper=USA Today|date=4 March 2008}}</ref> According to [[Interpol]], the files found by Colombian forces were considered to be authentic.<ref name="INTERPOLfarc">{{cite news|last=Forero|first=Juan|title=FARC Computer Files Are Authentic, Interpol Probe Finds|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/15/AR2008051504153.html|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=6 March 2013|date=16 May 2008}}</ref> In 2008, the [[United States Department of Treasury]] accused two senior Venezuelan government officials and one former official of providing material assistance for drug-trafficking operations carried out by the FARC guerrilla group in Colombia.<ref>{{cite web|title = Treasury Targets Venezuelan Government Officials Supporting the FARC|url = http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/hp1132.aspx|work = Press Release|publisher = United States Department of Treasury|accessdate = 5 March 2014}}</ref>
However, independent analyses of the documents by some U.S. academics and journalists have challenged the Colombian interpretation of the documents, accusing the Colombian government of exaggerating their contents.<ref name="Palast, Greg">{{cite web | url=http://www.gregpalast.com/300-million-from-chavez-to-farc-a-fake/ | title=$300 MILLION FROM CHAVEZ TO FARC A FAKE | publisher=Tomaine.com/Ourfuture.org | date=16 May 2008 | accessdate=2 August 2014 | author=Palast, Greg}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.derechos.org/nizkor/colombia/doc/paz/open.html | title=Interpol Analysis of FARC Laptop Authenticity Will Not "Prove" Links Between Venezuela, Rebels | publisher=derechos.org | date=25 April 2008 | accessdate=2 August 2014}}</ref> In 2008, the Secretary General of the [[Organization of American States]], [[Jose Miguel Insulza]], testified before the U.S. Congress that "there are no evidences" that Venezuela is supporting "terrorist groups", including the FARC.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.eluniversal.com/2008/04/10/en_pol_art_oas-insulza:-there_10A1509639|title = OAS' INSULZA: THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF VENEZUELAN SUPPORT TO TERRORISTS|publisher = El Universal|date = 10 April 2008|accessdate = 2 August 2014}}</ref> Three years later in 2011, the [[International Institute for Strategic Studies]] (IISS) concluded that Chavez's government funded FARC's Caracas office and granted it access to intelligence services. Venezuelan diplomats denounced the IISS' findings saying that they had "basic inaccuracies".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/americas/05/10/venezuela.farc.documents/index.html|title=Study: Colombian rebels were willing to kill for Venezuela's Chavez|last=Martinez|first=Michael|date=10 May 2011|newspaper=CNN|accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref>
Nevertheless, as of 2018, [[FARC dissidents]] who left FARC when it disbanded in 2017 still operate within Venezuela with virtual impunity. These dissident forces, with armed personnel numbering up to 2,500 individuals, allegedly still cooperate with the Cartel of the Suns.<ref name=":02" />
==See also== * [[State within a state|Deep state]] * [[Controversies surrounding Army of the Guardians of the Islamic Revolution]] * [[Illegal drug trade in Colombia]] * [[Susurluk scandal]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: consistent with title
Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/81.147.11.172|81.147.11.172]] ([[User talk:81.147.11.172|talk]]) to last revision by WikiWarfarin. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
'''Cost-effectiveness analysis''' ('''CEA''') is a form of [[economic]] [[financial analysis|analysis]] that compares the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action. Cost-effectiveness analysis is distinct from [[cost–benefit analysis]], which assigns a monetary value to the measure of effect.<ref name=CEAvCBA>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bleichrodt H, Quiggin J |title=Life-cycle preferences over consumption and health: when is cost-effectiveness analysis equivalent to cost-benefit analysis? |journal=J Health Econ |volume=18 |issue=6 |pages=681–708 |date=December 1999 |pmid=10847930 |doi= 10.1016/S0167-6296(99)00014-4|url=}}</ref> Cost-effectiveness analysis is often used in the field of health services, where it may be inappropriate to [[monetize]] health effect. Typically the CEA is expressed in terms of a ratio where the denominator is a gain in health from a measure (years of life, premature births averted, sight-years gained) and the numerator is the cost associated with the health gain.<ref>{{cite book | author = Gold MR | title = Cost-effectiveness in health and medicine | page = xviii|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The most commonly used outcome measure is [[quality-adjusted life year]]s (QALY).<ref name=CEAvCBA/>
[[Cost-utility analysis]] is similar to cost-effectiveness analysis. Cost-effectiveness analyses are often visualized on a plane consisting of [[Quadrant (plane geometry)|four-quadrants]], the cost represented on one axis and the effectiveness on the other axis.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Black|first=William|title=A Graphical Representation of Cost-Effectiveness.|journal=Med Decis Making|year=1990|volume=10|issue=3|pages=212–214|doi=10.1177/0272989x9001000308}}</ref> Cost-effectiveness analysis focuses on maximising the average level of an outcome, [[distributional cost-effectiveness analysis]] extends the core methods of CEA to incorporate concerns for the distribution of outcomes as well as their average level and make trade-offs between equity and efficiency, these more sophisticated methods are of particular interest when analysing interventions to tackle [[health inequality]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Asaria|first1=M|last2=Griffin|first2=S|last3=Cookson|first3=R|title=Distributional Cost-Effectiveness Analysis: A Tutorial.|journal=Medical decision making : an international journal of the Society for Medical Decision Making|date=January 2016|volume=36|issue=1|pages=8–19|pmid=25908564|doi=10.1177/0272989x15583266|pmc=4853814}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Asaria|first1=M|last2=Griffin|first2=S|last3=Cookson|first3=R|last4=Whyte|first4=S|last5=Tappenden|first5=P|title=Distributional cost-effectiveness analysis of health care programmes--a methodological case study of the UK Bowel Cancer Screening Programme.|journal=Health economics|date=June 2015|volume=24|issue=6|pages=742–54|pmid=24798212|doi=10.1002/hec.3058}}</ref>
==Applications==
The concept of cost-effectiveness is applied to the planning and management of many types of organized activity. It is widely used in many aspects of life. In the acquisition of military [[tank]]s, for example, competing designs are compared not only for purchase price, but also for such factors as their operating [[radius]], top speed, [[rate of fire]], armor protection, and caliber and armor [[penetration (weapons)|penetration]] of their guns. If a tank's performance in these areas is equal or even slightly inferior to its competitor, but substantially less expensive and easier to produce, military planners may select it as more cost effective than the competitor.
Conversely, if the difference in price is near zero, but the more costly competitor would convey an enormous battlefield advantage through special ammunition, [[radar]] [[Fire-control system|fire control]] and [[laser]] [[range finding]], enabling it to destroy enemy tanks accurately at extreme ranges, military planners may choose it instead—based on the same cost-effectiveness principle.
===In pharmacoeconomics===
In the context of [[pharmacoeconomics]], the cost-effectiveness of a therapeutic or preventive intervention is the ratio of the cost of the intervention to a relevant measure of its effect. Cost refers to the resource expended for the intervention, usually measured in monetary terms such as [[dollar]]s or [[pound sterling|pounds]]. The measure of effects depends on the intervention being considered. Examples include the number of people cured of a disease, the mm Hg reduction in diastolic [[blood pressure]] and the number of symptom-free days experienced by a patient. The selection of the appropriate effect measure should be based on clinical judgment in the context of the intervention being considered.
A special case of CEA is [[cost–utility analysis]], where the effects are measured in terms of years of full health lived, using a measure such as [[quality-adjusted life year]]s or [[disability-adjusted life year]]s. Cost-effectiveness is typically expressed as an [[incremental cost-effectiveness ratio]] (ICER), the ratio of change in costs to the change in effects. A complete compilation of cost-utility analyses in the peer reviewed medical literature is available from the [[Cost-Effectiveness Analysis Registry]] website.
A 1995 study of the cost-effectiveness of over 500 life-saving medical interventions found that the median cost per intervention was $42,000 per life-year saved.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tengs TO, Adams ME, Pliskin JS |title=Five-hundred life-saving interventions and their cost-effectiveness |journal=Risk Anal. |volume=15 |issue=3 |pages=369–90 |date=June 1995 |pmid=7604170 |doi= 10.1111/j.1539-6924.1995.tb00330.x|url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref> A 2006 systematic review found that industry-funded studies often concluded with cost effective ratios below $20,000 per QALY and low quality studies and those conducted outside the US and EU were less likely to be below this threshold. While the two conclusions of this article may indicate that industry-funded ICER measures are lower methodological quality than those published by non-industry sources, there is also a possibility that, due to the nature of retrospective or other non-public work, publication bias may exist rather than methodology biases. There may be incentive for an organization not to develop or publish an analysis that does not demonstrate the value of their product. Additionally, peer reviewed journal articles should have a strong and defendable methodology, as that is the expectation of the peer-review process.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bell CM, Urbach DR, Ray JG |title=Bias in published cost effectiveness studies: systematic review.|journal=BMJ |volume=332 |issue=7543 |pages=699–703 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16495332 |pmc=1410902 |doi=10.1136/bmj.38737.607558.80 |url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
===In energy efficiency investments=== CEA has been applied to [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] investments in buildings to calculate the value of energy saved in $/kWh. The energy in such a calculation is virtual in the sense that it was never consumed but rather saved due to some energy efficiency investment being made. Such savings are sometimes called ''[[negawatt]]s''. The benefit of the CEA approach in energy systems is that it avoids the need to guess future energy prices for the purposes of the calculation, thus removing the major source of uncertainty in the appraisal of energy efficiency investments.<ref>Pekka Tuominen, Francesco Reda, Waled Dawoud, Bahaa Elboshy, Ghada Elshafei, Abdelazim Negm: [http://doi.org/10.1016/S2212-5671(15)00195-1 Economic Appraisal of Energy Efficiency in Buildings Using Cost-effectiveness Assessment]. Procedia Economics and Finance, Volume 21, 2015, Pages 422–430.</ref>
==See also== *[[Cost–benefit analysis]] *[[Cost overrun]] *[[Efficiency]] *[[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]] *[[Distributional cost-effectiveness analysis]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/4420584.stm Why some drugs are not worth it] BBC report * [http://www.who.int/choice/en/ World Health Organization - CHOICE Choosing Interventions that are Cost Effective] * [http://ispor.co.googlepages.com ISPOR-CO, The Colombian Chapter of The International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research] * [https://iceaaonline.org International Cost Estimating and Analysis Association]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Dimitri Venediktov
{{small|Дмитрий Венедиктов}} |order = |title = [[Deputy Health Minister of the Soviet Union]] |image = |caption = |predecessor = |successor = |footnotes = ---- {{Collapsible list |titlestyle = background-color:#FFCCFF; |title = Other offices held |bullets = on |1989–1991: People's Deputy of the [[Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union]] }} |signature = |order2 = |deputy2 = |predecessor2 = |successor2 = |party = [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Soviet Communist]] |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = Russian |spouse = |children = |alma_mater = [[I.M. Sechenov First Moscow State Medical University]] |website = |term_start = 1965 |term_end = 1981 |order3 = |birthname = |death_cause = |education = [[Medicine]] }} '''Dimitri Venediktov''' was the Deputy Health Minister of the [[USSR]] from 1965 to 1981 under [[Ministry of Health (Soviet Union)|Ministers of Health]] [[Boris Petrovsky]] and [[Sergei Burenkov]].Дмитрий Венедиктов — Заведующий кафедрой медицинской информатики и управления при Президиуме РАМН — Кто есть Кто в медицине. Ktovmedicine.ru (2017). at In this role, he was instrumental in the [[Eradication of smallpox|campaign to eradicate smallpox]] and supplying vaccines for the program Henderson, D. Smallpox. 101-103 (Prometheus Books, 2009) a. He was also involved in organizing the [[Declaration of Alma-Ata|Conference of Alma-Ata]] which was foundational in the field of [[public health]].WHO | Consensus during the Cold War: back to Alma-Ata. Who.int (2017). at He was elected to the [[Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union]] from 1989 to its dissolution. He currently serves on the [[Russian Academy of Medical Sciences]], focusing on information storage in healthcare. == Awards == Venediktov received two [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour|Orders of the Red Banner of Labour]] and one [[Order of the Badge of Honour]] amongst other awards. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Venediktov, Dimitri}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Soviet physicians]] [[Category:Full Members of the USSR Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Full Members of the Russian Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Academicians of the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences]] [[Category:Smallpox eradication]] {{USSR-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: Typo fixing, replaced: environnemental → environmental - English spelling here. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Directed differentiation''' is a [[bioengineering]] [[methodology]] at the interface of [[stem cell biology]], [[developmental biology]] and [[tissue engineering]].<ref name="nih">{{cite journal|vauthors=Cohen DE, Melton D|title=Turning straw into gold: directing cell fate for regenerative medicine|journal=Nature Reviews Genetics|volume=12|issue=4|pages=243–252|year= 2011|doi=10.1038/nrg2938|pmid=21386864|publisher=[[National Center for Biotechnology Information]]}}</ref> It is essentially harnessing the potential of stem cells by constraining their [[Cell differentiation|differentiation]] in vitro toward a specific [[cell type]] or [[tissue (biology)|tissue]] of interest.<ref name="cell">{{cite journal|url=http://www.cell.com/cell/abstract/S0092-8674%2808%2900216-X|title=Differentiation of embryonic stem cells to clinically relevant populations: lessons from embryonic development|journal=Cell|accessdate=2014-11-06|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2008.02.008|volume=132|issue=4|pages=661–680|year=2008|vauthors=Murry CE, Keller G|pmid=18295582}}</ref> [[Stem cells]] are by definition [[pluripotent]], able to differentiate into several cell types such as [[neurons]],<ref name="nih2">{{cite journal|title=Directed differentiation of embryonic stem cells into motor neurons|journal=Cell|pmid=12176325|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|doi=10.1016/S0092-8674(02)00835-8|vauthors=Wichterle H, Lieberam I, Porter JA, Jessell TM|volume=110|issue=3|pages=385–397|year=2002}}</ref> [[cardiomyocytes]], [[hepatocytes]], etc. Efficient ''directed differentiation'' requires a detailed understanding of the lineage and [[Cell differentiation|cell fate]] decision, often provided by developmental biology.<ref name="cell"/><ref name="nih3">{{cite journal|title=Guiding embryonic stem cells towards differentiation: lessons from molecular embryology|journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development|volume=16|issue=5|year=2006|pages=469–475|vauthors=Spagnoli FM, Hemmati-Brivanlou A|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|pmid=16919445|doi=10.1016/j.gde.2006.08.004}}</ref>
==Conceptual frame== During differentiation, [[pluripotent]] cells make a number of developmental decisions to generate first the three [[germ layer]]s (ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm) of the embryo and intermediate progenitors,<ref name="cshlp">{{cite journal|url=http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/19/10/1129.long|title=Embryonic stem cell differentiation: emergence of a new era in biology and medicine|publisher=genesdev.cshlp.org|accessdate=2014-11-06|author=Keller G}}</ref> followed by subsequent decisions or check points, giving rise to all the body's mature tissues.<ref name="nih3"/> The differentiation process can be modeled as sequence of binary decisions based on [[probabilistic]] or [[stochastic]] models. Developmental biology and embryology provides the basic knowledge of the cell types' differentiation through [[mutation]] analysis, lineage tracing, embryo micro-manipulation and [[gene expression]] studies. Cell differentiation and tissue [[organogenesis]] involve a limited set of [[Signaling pathways|developmental signaling pathways]].<ref name="nih3"/> It is thus possible to direct cell fate by controlling cell decisions through extracellular signaling, mimicking developmental signals.
==Source material== ''Directed differentiation'' is primarily applied to [[pluripotent stem cell]]s (PSCs) of mammalian origin, in particular mouse and human cells for [[biomedical research]] applications.<ref name="cshlp"/> Since the discovery of [[Embryonic stem cells|embryonic stem]] (ES) cells (1981) and [[Induced pluripotent stem cells|induced pluripotent stem]] (iPS) cells (2006), source material is potentially unlimited.<ref name="nih"/><ref name="nih3"/><ref name="nih4">{{cite journal|title=Investigating human disease using stem cell models|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|vauthors=Sterneckert JL, Reinhardt P, Schöler HR|journal=Nature Reviews Genetics|volume=15|issue=9|pages=625–639|year=2014|doi=10.1038/nrg3764|pmid=25069490}}</ref> Historically, [[P19 cell|embryonic carcinoma]] (EC) cells have also been used.<ref name="nih5">{{cite journal|title=Retinoic acid induces embryonal carcinoma cells to differentiate into neurons and glial cells|publisher=The Rockefeller University Press|pmid=7107698|pmc=2112882|vauthors=Jones-Villeneuve EM, McBurney MW, Rogers KA, Kalnins VI|journal=The Journal of Cell Biology|year=1982|volume=94|issue=2|pages=253–262|doi=10.1083/jcb.94.2.253}}</ref> Fibroblasts or other differentiated cell types have been used for [[Examples of in vitro transdifferentiation by lineage-instructive approach|direct reprogramming]] strategies.<ref name="nih"/>
==Methods== Cell differentiation involves a transition from a proliferative mode toward differentiation mode. ''Directed differentiation'' consists in mimicking developmental (embryo's development) decisions in vitro using the stem cells as source material.<ref name="nih"/> For this purpose, pluripotent stem cells (PSCs) are cultured in controlled conditions involving specific substrate or [[extracellular matrices]] promoting cell adhesion and differentiation, and define [[Chemically defined medium|culture media]] compositions.<ref name="nih3"/> A limited number of signaling factors such as [[growth factors]] or [[small molecules]], controlling cell differentiation, is applied sequentially or in a combinatorial manner, at varying [[Dose (biochemistry)|dosage]] and exposure time.<ref name="nih"/> Proper differentiation of the cell type of interest is verified by analyzing [[Biomarker|cell type specific markers]], [[gene expression]] profile, and functional assays.<ref name="nih"/>
===Early methods=== * co-culture with [[stromal cells]] or [[feeder cell]]s, and on specific culture substrates: support cells and matrices provide developmental-like environmental signals.<ref name="nih6">{{cite journal|title=Embryonic stem-cell culture as a tool for developmental cell biology|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|pmid=17522593|vauthors=Nishikawa S, Jakt LM, Era T|journal=Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology|volume=8|issue=6|pages=502–507|year=2007| doi=10.1038/nrm2189}}</ref> * 3D cell aggregate formation, termed [[Embryoid body|embryoid bodies]] (EBs): the aggregate aim at mimicking early embryonic development and instructing the cell differentiation.<ref name="nih"/><ref name="cshlp"/><ref name="nih6"/> * culture in presence of [[fetal bovine serum]], removal of pluripotency factors.
===Current methodologies===
====Directed differentiation==== This method consists in exposing the cells to specific signaling pathways modulators and manipulating cell culture conditions (environmental or exogenous) to mimick the natural sequence of developmental decisions to produce a given cell type/tissue.<ref name="nih"/><ref name="nih6"/> A drawback of this approach is the necessity to have a good understanding of how the cell type of interest is formed.<ref name="nih"/>
====Direct reprogramming==== This method, also known as [[transdifferentiation]] or direct conversion, consists in overexpressing one or several factors, usually transcription factors, introduced in the cells.<ref name="nih"/> The starting material can be either pluripotent stem cells (PSCs), or either differentiated cell type such as fibroblasts. The principle was first demonstrated in 1987 with the myogenic factors MyoD.<ref name="nih7">{{cite journal|title=Expression of a single transfected cDNA converts fibroblasts to myoblasts. |vauthors=Davis RL, Weintraub H, Lassar AB|journal=Cell|volume=51|issue=6|pages=987–1000|year=1987|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|pmid=3690668|doi=10.1016/0092-8674(87)90585-X}}</ref> A drawback of this approach is the introduction of foreign nucleic acid in the cells and the forced expression of transcription factors which effects are not fully understood.
====Lineage/cell type-specific selection==== This methods consists in selecting the cell type of interest, usually with [[antibiotic resistance]]. For this purpose, the source material cells are modified to contain antibiotic resistance cassette under a target cell type specific [[Promoter (genetics)|promoter]].<ref name="nih8">{{cite journal|title=Endothelial cells genetically selected from differentiating mouse embryonic stem cells incorporate at sites of neovascularization in vivo|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|pmid=11973349|doi=|journal=Journal of Cell Science|year=2002|volume=115|issue=Pt 10|pages=2075–2085|vauthors=Marchetti S, Gimond C, Iljin K, Bourcier C, Alitalo K, Pouysségur J, Pagès G}}</ref><ref name="nih9">{{cite journal|title=Genetically selected cardiomyocytes from differentiating embronic stem cells form stable intracardiac grafts|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|vauthors=Klug MG, Soonpaa MH, Koh GY, Field LJ|pmid=8690796|pmc=507419|doi=10.1172/JCI118769|journal=Journal of Clinical Investigation|year=1996|volume=98|issue=1|pages=216–224.}}</ref> Only cells committed to the lineage of interest is surviving the [[Selection (biology)|selection]].
==Applications== ''Directed differentiation'' provides a potentially unlimited and manipulable source of cell and tissues. Some applications are impaired by the [[Developmental biology|immature phenotype]] of the pluripotent stem cells (PSCs)-derived cell type, which limits the physiological and functional studies possible.<ref name="nih4"/> Several application domains emerged:
===Model system for basic science=== For [[basic science]], notably [[developmental biology]] and [[cell biology]], [[Stem cell|PSC]]-derived cells allow to study at the molecular and cellular levels fundamental questions in vitro,<ref name="cshlp"/> that would have been otherwise extremely difficult or impossible to study for technical and ethical reasons in vivo such as embryonic development of human. In particular, differentiating cells are amenable for quantitative and qualitative studies.<ref name="nih6"/> More complex processes can also be studied in vitro and formation of organoids, including cerebroids, [[Optic cup (embryology)|optic cup]] and [[kidney]] have been described.
===[[Drug discovery]] and [[toxicology]]=== Cell types differentiated from pluripotent stem cells (PSCs) are being evaluated as [[preclinical]] in vitro models of Human diseases.<ref name="cshlp"/> Human cell types in a dish provide an alternative to traditional preclinical assays using animal, human [[immortalized cells]] or primary cultures from [[biopsies]], which their limitations. Clinically-relevant cell types i.e. cell type affected in diseases are a major focus of research, this includes [[hepatocytes]], [[Islets of Langerhans|Langerhans islet]] [[beta-cells]],<ref name="nih10">{{cite journal|title=Differentiation of embryonic stem cells to insulin-secreting structures similar to pancreatic islets|vauthors=Lumelsky N, Blondel O, Laeng P, Velasco I, Ravin R, McKay R|journal=Science|year=2001| volume=292|issue=5520|pages=1389–1394|doi=10.1126/science.1058866|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information|pmid=11326082}}</ref> [[cardiomyocytes]] and [[neurons]]. [[Drug screen]] are performed on miniaturized cell culture in multiwell-plates or on a chip.<ref name="nih4"/>
===Disease modeling=== PSCs-derived cells from patients are used in vitro to recreate specific pathologies.<ref name="nih4"/> The specific cell type affected in the pathology is at the base of the model. For example, motoneurons are used to study [[spinal muscular atrophy]] (SMA) and cardiomyocytes<ref name="cell"/> are used to study [[arrythmia]]. This can allow for a better understanding of the [[pathogenesis]] and the development of new treatments through drug discovery.<ref name="nih4"/> Immature PSC-derived cell types can be matured in vitro by various strategies, such as [[in vitro ageing]], to modelize age-related disease in vitro. Major diseases being modelized with PSCs-derived cells are [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS), [[Alzheimer's]] (AD), [[Parkinson's]] (PD), [[fragile X syndrome]] (FXS), [[Huntington disease]] (HD), [[Down syndrome]], Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), [[muscular dystrophies]],<ref name="pmid26237517">{{cite journal |vauthors = Chal J, Oginuma M, Al Tanoury Z, Gobert B, Sumara O, Hick A, Bousson F, Zidouni Y, Mursch C, Moncuquet P, Tassy O, Vincent S, Miyanari A, Bera A, Garnier JM, Guevara G, Hestin M, Kennedy L, Hayashi S, Drayton B, Cherrier T, Gayraud-Morel B, Gussoni E, Relaix F, Tajbakhsh S, Pourquié O|title = Differentiation of pluripotent stem cells to muscle fiber to model Duchenne muscular dystrophy |journal = [[Nat. Biotechnol.|Nature Biotechnology]]|date = August 2015|pmid = 26237517|doi = 10.1038/nbt.3297 |volume=33 |pages=962–9}} {{Closed access}}</ref><ref name="meth">{{cite journal|vauthors=Shelton M, Kocharyan A, Liu J, Skerjanc IS, Stanford WL|title = Robust generation and expansion of skeletal muscle progenitors and myocytes from human pluripotent stem cells|journal=Methods|date=2016|pmid=26404920|doi=10.1016/j.ymeth.2015.09.019|volume=101|pages=73–84}}{{Closed access}}</ref> [[cystic fibrosis]], [[Long QT syndrome]], and [[Type I diabetes]].<ref name="nih4"/>
===Regenerative medicine=== The potentially unlimited source of cell and tissues may have direct application for [[tissue engineering]], cell replacement and [[organ transplantation|transplantation]] following acute injuries and [[reconstructive surgery]].<ref name="cell"/><ref name="cshlp"/> These applications are limited to the cell types that can be differentiated efficiently and safely from human PSCs with the proper [[organogenesis]].<ref name="nih"/> Decellularized organs are also being used as tissue scaffold for organogenesis. Source material can be normal healthy cells from another donor (heterologous transplantation) or genetically corrected from the same patient (autologous). Concerns on patient safety have been raised due to the possibility of contaminating undifferentiated cells. The first clinical trial using hESC-derived cells was in 2011.<ref name="washingtonpost">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/first-test-of-human-embryonic-stem-cell-therapy-in-people-discontinued/2011/11/14/gIQAQBTOMN_story.html|title=First test of human embryonic stem cell therapy in people discontinued - The Washington Post|publisher=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=2014-11-06}}</ref> The first clinical trial using hiPSC-derived cells started in 2014 in Japan.<ref name="japantimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/09/12/national/science-health/japanese-ips-based-retina-transplant-a-global-first/#.VFmnIBZ5fYE|title=Japanese team first to use iPS cells in bid to restore human sight | The Japan Times|publisher=japantimes.co.jp|accessdate=2014-11-06}}</ref>
