revision.text:
[[File:Longlogopage.png|alt=EFB's Logo|thumb|Logo of the European Federation of Biotechnology]] The '''European Federation of Biotechnology''' (EFB) was established by European scientists in 1978. It is a non-profit federation of national biotechnology associations, learned societies, universities, scientific institutes, biotechnology companies and individual biotechnologists working to promote biotechnology throughout Europe and beyond.
The mission of the EFB is to promote the safe, sustainable and beneficial use of the life sciences, to promote research and innovation at the cutting edge of biotechnology, to provide a forum for interdisciplinary and international cooperation, to improve scientific education and to facilitate an informed dialogue between scientists, the biotechnology industries and the public.
The EFB Central Office (ECO) is located in Barcelona, Spain. Membership administration, organization of Executive Board meetings and General Assemblies, website management and organization of scientific meetings for EFB Sections and promotion of the European Congresses on Biotechnology are some of the main responsibilities of ECO. <ref>[http://www.efbiotechnology.org]</ref>
==European Congress on Biotechnology== [[File:ECB2018 Logo.png|alt=ECB2018 Logo|thumb|Logo of the European Congress on Biotechnology 2018]] The European Congress on Biotechnology (ECB) is a conference for academic and industrial biotechnologists in Europe, organised by the European Federation of Biotechnology.
The first Congress in the series was held in 1978 (Interlaken, Switzerland). As in all of the earlier congresses, the principal aim of the current ECB2018 is bring together the international scientific community and many segments of the biotech industry. The Congress will present the latest developments in front-line research and provide a platform for exchanging ideas in biotechnology and its applications. Participants will be able to interact with business leaders, investors, trade exhibitors and policy makers to discuss regulatory issues and the bioeconomy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ecb2018.com/|title=ECB 2018 {{!}} 1st - 4th July 2018|website=www.ecb2018.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
==Journal== ''[https://www.journals.elsevier.com/new-biotechnology/ New Biotechnology]'' is the official journal of the European Federation of Biotechnology (EFB) and is published bimonthly. It covers both the science of biotechnology and its surrounding political, business and financial milieu. The journal publishes peer-reviewed basic research papers, authoritative reviews, feature articles and opinions in all areas of biotechnology. It reflects the full diversity of current biotechnology science, particularly those advances in research and practice that open opportunities for exploitation of knowledge, commercially or otherwise, together with news, discussion and comment on broader issues of general interest and concern. The outlook is fully international.
== Notes and references == [http://www.efbiotechnology.org] [http://www.ecb2018.com/]
==See also== * [[EuropaBio]] * [[FlandersBio]] * [[EuCheMS]] * [[European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations]] (EFPIA) * [[Directorate-General for Research (European Commission)|Directorate-General for Research]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * EFB Website [http://www.efbiotechnology.org/ European Federation of Biotechnology] * ECB2018 [http://www.ecb2018.com/] * New Biotechnology [http://www.journals.elsevier.com/new-biotechnology/#description]

/* External links */
revision.text:
The '''Federation of the European Biochemical Societies''', frequently abbreviated '''FEBS''' is an international scientific society promoting activities in [[biochemistry]], [[molecular biology]] and molecular [[biophysics]] in [[Europe]]. Since it was founded in 1964 it has grown to include almost 40,000 members from 36 member societies and 7 associated societies from 43 countries [http://www.febs.org/index.php?id=64].
== Present activities == FEBS sponsors advanced courses for [[Ph.D.]]-students and [[postdoc]]s, arranges [[scientific conference|conferences]] and awards [[scholarship|fellowship]]s, awards and medals. FEBS distributes surplus scientific equipment in the poorer member countries as a part of the Scientific Apparatus Recycling Scheme (SARS). In addition, FEBS gives young scientists from [[Eastern Europe|Eastern]] and [[Central Europe]] a possibility to visit and work in labs in [[Western Europe]]. FEBS collaborates with related scientific societies such as the [[European Molecular Biology Organization]] (EMBO), [[European Life Scientist Organisation]] (ELSO), and the [[European Molecular Biology Laboratory]] (EMBL). FEBS is also founding member of the [[Initiative for Science in Europe]].
==Sir Hans Krebs Lecture and Medal== The [[Sir Hans Krebs Medal]] is awarded annually for outstanding achievements in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology or related sciences. It was endowed by the Lord Rank Centre for Research and named after the German-born British biochemist [[Hans Adolf Krebs]], well known for identifying the [[urea cycle|urea]] and [[citric acid cycle]]s. The awardee receives a silver medal and presents one of the plenary lectures at the FEBS Congress.<ref name = FEBSA>{{cite web|url =http://www.febs.org/our-activities/awards/medals|title= FEBS Medals|publisher= Federation of European Biochemical Societies|accessdate= 16 December 2014}}</ref>
==Datta Lectureship and Medal== The Datta Lectureship award is awarded for outstanding achievements in the field of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology or related sciences. The award is endowed by capital gifts from [[Elsevier Science Publishers]] and is named after S. Prakash Datta, the first Managing Editor of FEBS Letters (1968–1985) and Treasurer of FEBS. The awardee, who should normally be from a FEBS country, receives a medal provided by Elsevier Science Publishers and presents one of the plenary lectures at the FEBS Congress.<ref name = FEBSA/>
==Theodor Bücher Lecture and Medal== The Theodor Bücher Lecture and Medal is awarded for outstanding achievements in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology or related sciences. It was endowed by a capital gift from Frau Ingrid Bücher to the Gesellschaft für Biochemie und Molekularbiologie (GBM) and is named after the German biochemist, [[Theodor Bücher]]. The awardee receives a silver medal and presents one of the plenary lectures at the FEBS Congress.<ref name = FEBSA/>
== Journals == FEBS publishes four scientific journals ''[[FEBS Journal]], [[FEBS Letters]]'', and ''[[Molecular Oncology (journal)|Molecular Oncology]]'' and ''FEBS Open Bio''. ''FEBS Journal'' was previously known as the ''European Journal of Biochemistry''. ''FEBS Journal'' publishes full length research reports, whereas ''FEBS Letters'' is dedicated to brief and rapid reports. ''FEBS Open Bio'' is an [[open access journal]].
== See also == * [[Life Sciences Switzerland]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.febs.org/|FEBS official website}}
{{Chemistry societies}} {{Portal bar|Science|Europe}}

revision.text:
'''Gummy smile''' also known as '''excessive gingival display''' is a smile that shows an excessive amount of gum under the upper lip. It is a common unaesthetic clinical condition, which can be caused by an abnormal [[tooth eruption|dental eruption]] (delayed passive eruption), or hyperfunction of the upper [[lip]] [[levator labii superioris alaeque nasi muscle|elevator muscle]] or by an excessive vertical growth of the bone of [[maxilla]] or over-eruption of the maxillary anterior teeth, or a combinations to one of the above described factors together.<ref name="Monaco_2004">{{cite journal | vauthors = Monaco A, Streni O, Marci MC, Marzo G, Gatto R, Giannoni M | title = Gummy smile: clinical parameters useful for diagnosis and therapeutical approach | journal = The Journal of Clinical Pediatric Dentistry | volume = 29 | issue = 1 | pages = 19–25 | date = 2004 | pmid = 15554398 | doi = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chandrasekharan D, Balaji SM | title = Intrusion of anterior teeth to improve smile esthetics | journal = Journal of Maxillofacial and Oral Surgery | volume = 9 | issue = 1 | pages = 27–9 | date = March 2010 | pmid = 23139562 | pmc = 3453683 | doi = 10.1007/s12663-010-0009-8 }}</ref> Several treatment options have been proposed to enhance the smile display and to reduce the [[gingival]] exposure.<ref name="pmid9533335">{{cite journal | vauthors = Levine RA, McGuire M | title = The diagnosis and treatment of the gummy smile | journal = Compendium of Continuing Education in Dentistry (Jamesburg, N.J. : 1995) | volume = 18 | issue = 8 | pages = 757–62, 764; quiz 766 | date = August 1997 | pmid = 9533335 | doi = }}</ref>
== Treatment ==
Treatment option include [[orthodontics]],<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chandrasekharan D, Balaji SM | title = Intrusion of anterior teeth to improve smile esthetics | journal = Journal of Maxillofacial and Oral Surgery | volume = 9 | issue = 1 | pages = 27–9 | date = March 2010 | pmid = 23139562 | doi = 10.1007/s12663-010-0009-8 | pmc = 3453683 }}</ref> [[Dental surgery|surgery]],<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Faus-Matoses V, Faus-Matoses I, Jorques-Zafrilla A, Faus-Llácer VJ | title = Lip repositioning technique. A simple surgical procedure to improve the smile harmony | journal = Journal of Clinical and Experimental Dentistry | volume = 10 | issue = 4 | pages = e408-e412 | date = April 2018 | pmid = 29750105 | pmc = 5937970 | doi = 10.4317/jced.54721 }}</ref> [[Botulinum toxin|botulinum toxin A]] injections,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sucupira E, Abramovitz A | title = A simplified method for smile enhancement: botulinum toxin injection for gummy smile | journal = Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery | volume = 130 | issue = 3 | pages = 726–8 | date = September 2012 | pmid = 22929256 | doi = 10.1097/PRS.0b013e31825dc32f }}</ref> and micro-autologous fat transplantation (MAFT).<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Huang SH, Huang YH, Lin YN, Lee SS, Chou CK, Lin TY, Takahashi H, Kuo YR, Lai CS, Lin SD, Lin TM | title = Micro-Autologous Fat Transplantation for Treating a Gummy Smile | journal = Aesthetic Surgery Journal | date = March 2018 | pmid = 29566216 | doi = 10.1093/asj/sjy069 }}</ref>
Botox ([[Botulinum toxin|BTX-A]]) has been successful in the treatment of [[Gums|gummy]] smiles, however the results are not permanent, they last for an average of 6 months.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Nayyar P, Kumar P, Nayyar PV, Singh A | title = BOTOX: Broadening the Horizon of Dentistry | journal = Journal of Clinical and Diagnostic Research | volume = 8 | issue = 12 | pages = ZE25-9 | date = December 2014 | pmid = 25654058 | pmc = 4316364 | doi = 10.7860/JCDR/2014/11624.5341 }}</ref> The material is injected into the hyperactive muscles of upper lip, which causes a reduction in the upward movement of lip thus resulting in a smile with a less exposure of [[Gums|gingiva]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Al-Fouzan AF, Mokeem LS, Al-Saqat RT, Alfalah MA, Alharbi MA, Al-Samary AE | title = Botulinum Toxin for the Treatment of Gummv Smile | journal = The Journal of Contemporary Dental Practice | volume = 18 | issue = 6 | pages = 474–478 | date = June 2017 | pmid = 28621277 }}</ref> Botox is usually injected in the three lip elevator muscles that converge on the lateral side of the ala of the nose; the [[levator labii superioris]] (LLS), the [[levator labii superioris alaeque nasi muscle]] (LLSAN), and the [[Zygomaticus minor muscle|zygomaticus minor]] (ZMi).<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hwang WS, Hur MS, Hu KS, Song WC, Koh KS, Baik HS, Kim ST, Kim HJ, Lee KJ | title = Surface anatomy of the lip elevator muscles for the treatment of gummy smile using botulinum toxin | journal = The Angle Orthodontist | volume = 79 | issue = 1 | pages = 70–7 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 19123705 | doi = 10.2319/091407-437.1 }}</ref>
== References == {{Portal|Dentistry}} {{Reflist|32em}}
[[Category:Dentistry]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox medical person | honorific_prefix = | name = John A. Kenney Sr. | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = {{birth date|1874|06|11}} | birth_place = [[Albemarle County, Virginia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1950|01|29|1874|06|11}} | death_place = [[Glen Ridge, New Jersey]] | death_cause = | nationality = | citizenship = | education = [[Hampton University]], [[Leonard Medical School]] | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | relations = [[John A. Kenney Jr.]] (son) | website = | profession = Surgeon | field = [[Surgery]] | work_institutions = | specialism = | research_field = | notable_works = | prizes = | child = | module2 = | signature = }} '''John Andrew Kenney Sr.''' (June 11, 1874{{snd}}January 29, 1950) was an African-American surgeon who was the medical director and chief surgeon of the [[John A. Andrew Memorial Hospital]] at the [[Tuskegee Institute]] in [[Tuskegee, Alabama]], from 1902 to 1922. He was also the co-founder of the [[National Medical Association]] (NMA), of which he also served as secretary from 1904 to 1912. He was elected president of the NMA in 1912.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/2003/12/07/john-a-kenney-jr-89/b26bfa6c-5c46-4f31-9540-11cefb734352/ |title=John A. Kenney Jr., 89 |date=2003-12-07 |work=Washington Post |access-date=2018-03-22 |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> He was the [[editor-in-chief]] of its journal, the ''[[Journal of the National Medical Association]]'', from 1916 to 1948.<ref>{{Cite journal |date=January 1956 |title=John Andrew Kenney, M.D., 1874-1950 |journal=Journal of the National Medical Association |volume=48 |issue=1 |pages=75 |pmc=2641163 |pmid=20893791}}</ref> After leaving Tuskegee in 1924, he founded the Kenney Memorial Hospital in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. This hospital was later renamed the Booker T. Washington Community Hospital in 1935, and closed down in 1953.<ref name=tuskegee/> He also served as the personal physician of both [[Booker T. Washington]]<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Morrison |first=Sheena M. |last2=Fee |first2=Elizabeth |date=2010-04-01 |title=The Journal of the National Medical Association: A Voice for Civil Rights and Social Justice |url=http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/10.2105/AJPH.2009.175042 |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=100 |issue=S1 |pages=S70–S71 |doi=10.2105/ajph.2009.175042 |issn=0090-0036|pmc=2837443 }}</ref> and [[George Washington Carver]].<ref name=tuskegee>{{Cite web |url=http://archive.tuskegee.edu/archive/bitstream/handle/123456789/96/John%20A.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y |title=Guide to the Papers of John A. Kenney |date=2009 |website=Tuskegee University|page=3}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kenney, John Andrew Sr.}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1950 deaths]] [[Category:African-American physicians]] [[Category:People from Albemarle County, Virginia]] [[Category:Hampton University alumni]] [[Category:Shaw University alumni]] [[Category:Medical journal editors]] [[Category:People from Tuskegee, Alabama]] [[Category:American surgeons]] [[Category:Physicians from Alabama]] [[Category:Physicians from New Jersey]] [[Category:Physicians from Virginia]]
{{surgeon-stub}}

page.title: List of fatal snake bites in the United States

revision.comment: /*References*/ Clean up a citation.
revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=August 2008}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} This is a '''list of some people who received a fatal snake bite in the United States''' by decade in reverse chronological order. There is no evidence it is a comprehensive list.
[[File:Crotalus adamanteus (5).jpg|thumb|300px|The eastern diamondback rattlesnake (''[[Crotalus adamanteus]]'') kills the most people in the US, with the western diamondback rattlesnake (''[[Crotalus atrox]]'') ranking second.<ref name="Nor-C&L04">Norris R (2004). "Venom Poisoning in North American Reptiles". '''''In'':''' [[Jonathan A. Campbell|Campbell JA]], Lamar WW (2004). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZYQpAQAAMAAJ ''The Venomous Reptiles of the Western Hemisphere'']. Ithaca and London: Comstock Publishing Associates. 870 pp., 1,500 plates. {{ISBN|0-8014-4141-2}}.{{Page needed|date=March 2013}}</ref> However, some authorities believe the western diamondback is responsible for the most deaths.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Reptiles and Amphibians: Eastern/Central North America|last=Conant|first=Roger|authorlink=Roger Conant (herpetologist)| last2=Collins|first2=Joseph T.|authorlink2=Joseph T. Collins|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|year=1998|isbn=0-395-90452-8|location=New York, New York|pages=412}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=A Field Guide to Venomous Animals and Poisonous Plants: North America North of Mexico|last=Foster|first=Steven, and Roger Caras|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|year=1994|isbn=|location=New York|pages=plate 2}}</ref>]]
== Snake species == The United States has about 20 species of venomous snakes, which include 16 species of [[rattlesnakes]], two species of [[coral snakes]], one species of [[cottonmouth]] (or water moccasin), and one species of [[Agkistrodon contortrix|copperhead]]. At least one species of venomous snake is found in every state except Alaska and Hawaii.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.venombyte.com/venom/snakes/venomous_snakes_by_state.asp|title=Venomous Snakes of the United States by State|first=David W.|last=George|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref>
It has been estimated that 7,000–8,000 people per year receive venomous snake bites in the United States, and about five of those people die.<ref>{{cite web |title=Venomous Snakes |url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/snakes/|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> Most fatal bites are attributed to the [[eastern diamondback rattlesnake]] and the [[western diamondback rattlesnake]]. The copperhead accounts for more cases of venomous snake bite than any other North American species; however, its venom is the least toxic, so its bite is seldom fatal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Copperhead snake page |publisher=Snakesandfrogs.com |url=http://www.snakesandfrogs.com/scra/snakes/copperh.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000916094157/http://www.snakesandfrogs.com/scra/snakes/copperh.htm |archivedate=2000-09-16 |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref>
Venomous snakes are distributed unevenly throughout the United States — the vast majority of snake bites occur in warm weather states. States like [[Florida]] and [[Texas]] have a wide variety and large population of venomous snakes. Bites from venomous snakes are extremely rare in the states near the [[Canada–United States border|Canada–US border]]. [[Maine]], for example, has only one species ([[timber rattlesnake]]); it is rarely seen, and then only in the southern part of the state, but the species is likely extirpated in Maine, with the last sighting in 1901.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newenglandreptile.com/timber.html|title=Timber Rattlesnakes|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
==2010s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Lawrence Walters, 70, male || June 4, 2018 || Rattlesnake || Spearfish, Lawrence County, South Dakota. Walters was playing golf at the Elkhorn Ridge Golf Course in Spearfish. He was looking for a ball in tall grass when he was bitten on the ankle. He was rushed back to the clubhouse in a cart where another employee performed CPR until an ambulance arrived, but was pronounced dead at Spearfish hospital..<ref>{{cite web | title=Black Hills golfer dies after bitten by rattlesnake |url=https://www.greatfallstribune.com/story/news/2018/06/11/black-hills-golfer-dies-after-bitten-rattlesnake/693245002/ |website=The Great Falls Tribune |accessdate=25 August 2018 |date=June 11, 2018}}</ref> |- | Barry Lester, 57, male || April 29, 2018 || Rattlesnake || Osage County, Oklahoma, Lester was driving down a road when he spotted the rattlesnake, he tried to move it to safety but ended up being bit on both hands, Lester collapsed shortly after and was pronounced dead.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Alanis |first1=Kaitlyn |title='You don't mess with snakes,' wife says after rattler kills husband on birthday trip |url=https://www.kansas.com/news/nation-world/national/article210310494.html |website=The Wichita Eagle |accessdate=9 July 2018 |date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> |- | Daniel Hohs, 31, male || October 7, 2017 || Rattlesnake || Hohs was bitten on the ankle while hiking near [[Golden, Colorado]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Hiker from Golden dies after being bitten by rattlesnake|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/10/07/hiker-dies-after-being-bitten-rattlesnake-jefferson-county/|publisher=Denver Post|accessdate=9 October 2017}}</ref> |- | Wayne Grooms, 71, male || June 12, 2016 || Rattlesnake (likely [[timber rattlesnake]]) || Grooms was in the [[Santee National Wildlife Refuge]] in South Carolina when a rattlesnake bit his lower left leg.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/state/south-carolina/article83632887.html|title=SC conservationist dies after rattlesnake bite at nature preserve|access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref> He collapsed and died within 15 minutes. He may have had an undisclosed condition which contributed to the severity of his reaction to the bite.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestate.com/news/local/article83824427.html|title=Autopsy confirms snake bite killed SC conservationist, coroner says|date=June 14, 2016}}</ref> [[Timber rattlesnake]]s are the most common in this refuge, but [[eastern diamondback rattlesnake]]s are adaptable, could potentially be found in this refuge, and are more likely to cause serious bites than timbers, due to their disposition and venomous potential.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Field Guide to Venomous Animals and Poisonous Plants: North America North of Mexico|last=Foster|first=Steven, and Roger Caras|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|year=1994|isbn=0-395-51594-7|location=New York|pages=14, 18}}</ref> |- |John David Brock, 60, male |July 28, 2015 |Unknown (almost certainly timber rattlesnake) |Brock was bitten during a religious service at a Pentecostal Church in Jenson, Kentucky. He refused treatment and died in his brother's home.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/kentucky-man-dies-from-snake-bite-at-church-service/|title=Kentucky man dies from snake bite at church service|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |- | Russell E. Davis, 39, male || July 19, 2015 || [[Timber rattlesnake]] || Davis was sitting by a fire at his family's camp in [[Elk County, Pennsylvania]] when he was bitten by a rattlesnake. He was taken to a hospital and from there airlifted to a Pittsburgh-area hospital. While in the helicopter, Davis suffered a cardiac arrest and was subsequently pronounced dead upon arrival to the hospital. The cause of death was an anaphylactic reaction from the snake's venom. No autopsy was performed and the death was ruled accidental.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kittanningpaper.com/2015/07/20/man-killed-by-elk-county-rattlesnake/56651|title=Man Killed by Elk County Rattlesnake}}</ref> |-
| Grant Thompson, 18, male || July 14, 2015 || [[Naja kaouthia|Monocled cobra]] || Thompson was found unresponsive in his car in a Lowe's store parking lot in North Austin, Texas. He was taken to a hospital where he was pronounced dead. A monocled cobra that he was known to own was missing and was later found dead nearby, having been run over by a car <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/ap/ap/texas/man-with-puncture-wounds-on-arm-dies-in-texas-snak/nmzBC/ |title=Temple man killed by Cobra in Austin |work=Statesman Online |date=15 July 2015 |accessdate=15 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150718080430/http://www.statesman.com/ap/ap/texas/man-with-puncture-wounds-on-arm-dies-in-texas-snak/nmzBC/ |archivedate=18 July 2015 |df= }}</ref> An autopsy was performed and Thompson's death was ruled a suicide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/news/local/autopsy-teen-used-cobra-to-committ-suicide/npMHz/|title=Autopsy: Teen used cobra to commit suicide|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |- | Gilbert De Leon, 37, male || May 23, 2015 || [[Agkistrodon piscivorus|Cottonmouth]] || De Leon was bitten on each leg while wading in the James River near [[Nixa, Missouri]]. After the bite, he did not seek medical attention and died the next day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3099453/Woman-wakes-boyfriend-37-dead-bed-one-day-bitten-poisonous-water-snake-refused-treatment.html|title=Missouri woman wakes to find boyfriend dead after he was bitten by water snake|work=Mail Online|date=27 May 2015|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> |- |David Giles, 59, male |May 20, 2015 |Unknown, but likely rattlesnake |Giles, of [[Watkinsville, Georgia]], was bitten while he was alone in [[Arnoldsville, Georgia]]. He normally carried a snakebite kit, but did not have it with him this time. He drove to a nearby house to seek help, and collapsed. A [[timber rattlesnake]] would have been the normal suspect, but since he was weakened by Lyme disease it could have been a pygmy, cottonmouth, or copperhead.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oconeeenterprise.com/news/article_0ed5546e-ff00-11e4-a74d-6b0eeeff7035.html|title=Snakebite claims life of Watkinsville man|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |- | Timothy Levins, 52, male || July 8, 2014 || [[Agkistrodon contortrix|Copperhead]] || While camping at [[Sam A. Baker State Park]] in Missouri, Levins walked outside, saw a snake, and brought it to his son's attention. When he picked it up, the snake bit him. Levins walked back into the cabin, washed his hand at the kitchen sink and sat down on the couch. When he became sick, someone from a neighboring cabin came over to help and performed CPR. Levins was later pronounced dead at an area hospital.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dean|first1=Dana|last2=Aja J.|first2=Williams|last3=Zigman|first3=Leisa|title=Snakebite kills Missouri man|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2014/07/13/snake-bite-missouri-man-dead-camping/12593291/|accessdate=20 August 2014|work=USAToday|date=July 13, 2014}}</ref> |- |Brayden Bullard, 4, male |June 20, 2014 |Timber rattlesnake |Bitten while planting watermelons in his backyard in Bryceville, Florida.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.news4jax.com/news/local/4-year-old-boy-bitten-by-rattlesnake|title=4-year-old boy bitten by rattlesnake|last=Winslow|first=Hailey|date=June 13, 2014|website=News4Jax|access-date=}}</ref> He was rushed to the hospital, but died 2 weeks later<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/crime/2014-06-20/story/two-weeks-after-rattlesnake-bite-nassau-county-boy-4-dies|title=Two weeks after rattlesnake bite, Nassau County boy, 4, dies|website=jacksonville.com|access-date=2016-03-15}}</ref> |- | [[Jamie Coots]], 42, male || Feb 15, 2014 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Coots was bitten on the right hand during a service at his Full Gospel Tabernacle in Jesus Name church in [[Middlesboro, Kentucky]]. After the bite, Coots dropped the snakes, but then picked them back up and continued the ceremony. Later, he was driven to his home. When paramedics arrived, his relatives refused medical treatment for him, saying it was inconsistent with his religion. He died at home. |- |Daniel Frank Mitchell, 53, male |Sept. 20, 2013 |Rattlesnake (probably eastern diamondback, but possibly timber) |Salem, Alabama<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.al.com/east-alabama/2013/09/cherokee_county_man_dies_from.html|title=Cherokee County man dies from rattlesnake bite, a rare occurrence in Alabama|website=AL.com|access-date=2016-03-15}}</ref> |- |Ernest Burch, 80, male |July 2, 2013<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.northwestgeorgianews.com/rome/news/local/armuchee-man-dies-from-rattlesnake-bite/article_0908796c-e472-11e2-9ec1-001a4bcf6878.html|title=Armuchee man dies from rattlesnake bite|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |[[Timber rattlesnake]] |Burch found the snake in his garage in [[Armuchee, Georgia]]. Not wanting to kill it, he tried moving it out with a broom but lost his balance, fell on top of the snake, and was bitten on his left arm. He was rushed to the hospital and received eight vials of antivenom, but died 30 hours later.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbs46.com/story/22788095/family-remembers-man-bitten-by-timber-rattlesnake|title=Family remembers man bitten by timber rattlesnake|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |Jack Redmond, 70, male |October 2, 2012 |Unknown |He was likely killed by one of the 24 venomous snakes he kept in his home in Chesterfield, Virginia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wtvr.com/2012/10/02/snakes-in-chesterfield-home/|title=Venomous snakes removed from home, man's death under investigation|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |Terry Brown, 50, male || July 2012 || [[Agkistrodon contortrix|Copperhead]] || Brown died of a heart attack one day after he was bitten by a copperhead snake while camping on the Current River, Missouri. The coroner's office listed the cause of death as a heart attack, with the snake bite as a contributing factor. Witnesses told investigators that Brown had seen a snake in one of the tents and was trying to remove it when the snake bit him on the right thumb.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/camper-dies-after-copperhead-bite-along-current-river/article_ad3fafde-c504-11e1-933b-001a4bcf6878.html|title=Camper dies after Copperhead bite along Current River|author=Tim O'Neil|date=July 4, 2012 |work=stltoday.com|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> |- | Mark Randall Wolford, 44, male || May 28, 2012 || [[Timber rattlesnake]] || Wolford was bitten on the thigh while handling a timber rattlesnake as part of an outdoor religious service at [[Panther Wildlife Management Area|Panther State Forest]] in [[McDowell County, West Virginia]].<ref name="WPAP">{{cite news |title=Snake-handling W.Va. preacher dies after suffering bite during outdoor service |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/snake-handling-wva-preacher-dies-of-what-witnesses-say-was-timber-rattlers-bite/2012/05/31/gJQAamJb4U_story.html |publisher=The Washington Post |agency=The Associated Press |date=May 31, 2012 |accessdate=12 June 2012}}{{dead link|date=August 2014}}</ref><ref name="BG">{{cite news|title=Snake-handling pastor dies after bite|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-31477024.html|accessdate=20 August 2014|work=The Boston Globe|date=June 1, 2012|via=HighBeam Research}}</ref> Wolford did not initially seek medical treatment for his injury, but was taken to Bluefield Regional Medical Center when his condition began to deteriorate some eight hours later.<ref name="WPAP"/> Wolford was a pastor and often handled his pet snake during church services.<ref name="WPAP"/> Wolford's father, Mack Wolford, died in 1983 under similar circumstances.<ref name="BDT">{{cite news |title=Web Extra: 1983 Daily Telegraph story detailing the death of Wolford's father, also from a snake bite |url=http://bdtonline.com/local/x1647292521/WEB-EXTRA-1983-Daily-Telegraph-story-detailing-the-death-of-Wolford-s-father-also-from-a-snake-bite |publisher=Bluefield Daily Telegraph |date=August 30, 1983 |accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> |- |Aleta Stacy, 56, female |June 2011 |presumably [[Black mamba|Black Mamba]] |Found dead in her home in Putnam Co., NY. She illegally kept numerous venomous snakes in her home, one of which was a Black Mamba.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/did-bite-from-black-mamba-kill-new-york-woman/|title=Did bite from black mamba kill New York woman?|last=Jaslow|first=Ryan|date=June 20, 2011|website=CBS News|access-date=}}</ref> Some suspect that her death was a suicide.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-2004770/Suicide-snake-Woman-killed-African-black-mamba-kept-New-York-home.html|title=Did she commit 'suicide by snake'? Woman killed by African black mamba she kept in New York home along with 75 others|last=|first=|date=20 June 2011|website=Daily Mail|access-date=}}</ref> |- |Mark Shaw, 47, male |April 5, 2011 |Rattlesnake (probably western diamondback, but possibly timber) |Shaw was bitten by a rattlesnake he was trying to kill in Bastrop County, Texas.<ref name="elgincourier.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.elgincourier.com/news/article_85baf5c2-710e-11e0-a08c-001cc4c03286.html|title=Paige man dies from rattlesnake bite|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |- | Wade Westbrook, 26, male || January 29, 2011 || [[Agkistrodon contortrix|Copperhead]] || Westbrook was bitten just above the right elbow while handling a copperhead; he had been attempting to determine the snake's sex.<ref name="Ghianni">{{cite news |title=Tennessee man dies from poisonous copperhead snake bite |author=Ghianni, Tim |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/31/us-snake-death-idUSTRE70U5HK20110131 |agency=Reuters |date=January 31, 2011 |accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> According to witnesses, he "tried to extract the venom with a tool after he was bitten, then he began coughing and vomiting before he collapsed."<ref name="WRCB">{{cite news |title=Updated: Official cause of death determined in snake bite case |author=Nicholson, Ken |url=http://www.wrcbtv.com/Global/story.asp?S=13940577 |publisher=WRCB |location=Chattanooga, Tennessee |date=January 31, 2011 |accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> Westbrook was pronounced dead on arrival at [[Erlanger Health System|Erlanger Hospital]] in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]].<ref name="WRCB"/> The cause of death was determined to be "anaphylactic shock as a result of the snake bite." Westbrook had been bitten previously by a Copperhead, which may have made him hypersensitive to snake venom.<ref name="WRCB"/> |- | William Price, 67, male || October 13, 2010 || Rattlesnake, probably a [[Crotalus oreganus helleri|Southern Pacific rattlesnake]] || Price was bitten above the right ankle while wading across a stream near Cuyamaca Reservoir in [[Cuyamaca, California]].<ref name="Repard">{{cite news |title=La Jolla man dies from rattlesnake bite |author=Repard, Pauline |url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2010/oct/15/la-jolla-man-dies-rattlesnake-bite/ |publisher=The San Diego Union-Tribune |date=October 15, 2010 |accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref> He had been taking part in a study of steelhead trout that was funded by a state Department of Fish and Game grant.<ref name="Repard"/> According to witnesses, Price "stopped breathing within minutes" of being bitten. The bite marks on his foot were reportedly an inch and a half across.<ref name="Repard"/> Price was airlifted to [[Palomar Medical Center]], but later died. |- |Peyton Hood, 1, female |Aug. 11, 2010 |Western diamondback rattlesnake |Accidentally stepped on baby Western Diamondback while climbing down ladder at Possum Kingdom Lake, Texas. The snake struck her main artery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newschannel6now.com/story/28534938/snake-bite-season|title=Snake Bite Season|website=www.newschannel6now.com|access-date=2016-03-15}}</ref> She was rushed to the hospital, but died within a few hours.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/living/family/moms/article3825924.html|title=Girl dies after snake bite near Possum Kingdom Lake|last=Miller|first=Bill|date=August 11, 2010|website=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |George Yancy, 35, male |May 9, 2010 |Rattlesnake (probably western diamondback, but possibly timber) |Yancy was bitten while pulling up his pants in Smithville, Texas.<ref name="elgincourier.com"/> |}
==2000s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Richard Rupert, 68, male|| October 10, 2009||[[Timber rattlesnake]]|| Rupert was hunting with his grandson in [[Oglethorpe County, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Boy couldn't save snakebit grandpa |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/news/local/boy-couldnt-save-snakebit-grandpa/nQYHf/ |date=Oct 13, 2009|author=Christian Boone|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|publisher=ajc.com|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> |- | James David Bear, 37, male|| January 29, 2008 ||[[Timber rattlesnake]]|| Bitten on his right thumb at his mobile house. The canebrake rattlesnake that bit him was one of 179 snakes he kept and bred in various containers and 84 of the snakes were venomous species.<ref>{{cite web |title=Deadly Rattlesnake Bite Leads to 179 Illegal Snakes |url=http://www.outdoors-411.com/news/wildlife/080201-illegal-snakes-snakebite.html}}</ref> |- | Jackie Ledwell, 63, female || October, 2007 || [[Mojave rattlesnake]] || Ledwell was bitten while taking a walk in Paulden, Arizona.<ref>{{cite web |title=Snakebite Deaths Still Rare but are Mounting |url=http://tucsoncitizen.com/morgue/2007/10/13/65431-snakebite-deaths-still-rare-but-are-mounting/ |accessdate=23 September 2013|work=tucsoncitizen.com}}</ref> |- |Linda Long, 48, female |November 5, 2006 |[[Rattlesnake]] |Long died after being bitten by a snake during a serpent-handling service at church.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/woman-dies-after-snakebite-in-church/|title=Woman Dies After Snakebite In Church|access-date=2018-05-23|language=en}}</ref> |- | Inocencio Hernandez-Hernandez, 29, male || June 10, 2006 || [[Eastern coral snake]] || Hernandez-Hernandez became the first person to die in the United States from a fatal coral snake bite since 1967. He and Jesus Moreida, both of [[Bonita Springs, Florida]], were bitten by a coral snake they tried to kill.<ref>{{cite web |title=Southeastern Outdoors – Fatal Coral Snake Bites |url=http://www.southeasternoutdoors.com/wildlife/reptiles/fatal-coral-snake-bites.html |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> |- | Joe Guidry, 54, male ||October 2005 || [[Eastern diamondback rattlesnake]] || Guidry, the [[Putnam County, Florida]], fire marshal, went to help a neighbor who had spotted a rattlesnake while mowing grass. He shot at the snake; it went under a shed, and Guidry was bitten when he reached for it.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20051011/LOCAL/51010045|title=Snake bite is deadly for Putnam fire official|work=[[The Gainesville Sun]]|author=Lise Fisher|date=October 11, 2005|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> |- | Marcus Wolf, 35, male || September 12, 2005 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Wolf, a German tourist, was bitten while hiking near [[Willcox, Arizona]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/221702259/|title=Snakebite Fatality Prompts Warning |work=Arizona Daily Star |location=Tucson, Arizona |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=2005-09-17 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Margaret Wilson White, 54, female ||July 2005 || [[Rattlesnake]] || White was bitten in [[Hays County, Texas]], near Wimberley along Ranch Road 12, about a quarter mile west of County Road 213.<ref>{{cite web|title=July 29, 2005 - Search for missing woman in Hays County | url=http://www.smartdivers.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=60:smartdivelog2005&catid=51:divelogs&Itemid=60}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wimberley Woman Missing |work=SAN MARCOS DAILY RECORD | author=Anita Miller|date=Jul 27, 2005|url=http://visitwimberley.com/ubb/Forum3/HTML/000435.html |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Missing woman found dead, bitten by snake|url=http://www.myplainview.com/article_ec3f1be8-0c4a-5131-8295-80ddda7b37b6.html|work=myplainview.com|date=August 1, 2005}}</ref> |- | Alexandria Hall, 44, female || September 6, 2004 || [[Bothrops alternatus|Urutu pit viper]] || Bitten at her home and died two days later from a bleed in the brain.<ref>{{cite news |title=Woman with venomous pets dies of bite |date=September 13, 2004 | publisher=Chicago Tribune |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-09-13/news/0409130117_1_venomous-viper-cincinnati-zoo |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Deadly snakes removed from victim's home |date=September 13, 2004 | publisher=UPI |url=https://www.upi.com/Deadly-snakes-removed-from-victims-home/17901095109510/ |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> |- | Trent Leprette, 31, male || June 2004 || [[Agkistrodon contortrix|Copperhead]] || Leprette was bitten on each hand while swimming in Saugahatchee Creek near Loachapoka, Alabama. He was admitted to East Alabama Medical Center in [[Opelika, Alabama|Opelika]]; he developed complications and died after several days of treatment.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fatal Snake Bite |date=June 23, 2004 |publisher=WTVY.com |url=http://www.wtvy.com/news/headlines/846297.html |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> |- | Ross Cooke, 50, male || May 2003 || [[Southern Pacific rattlesnake]] || Cooke was killed in Lyle Creek, [[San Bernardino County, California]], having stepped on a snake he mistook for a log.<ref>[https://deepcreekhotsprings.net/dchs/forum/read.php?1,5577,5577|"NORCO: Snakebite called unusual, George Watson, Paige Watson, Press Enterprise, 23 May 2003]</ref> |- |- | Pat Hughes, 45, male || August 2002 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Hughes was bitten on the finger by a small snake in his own garage. He was admitted to Sierra Vista Regional Health Center in [[Sierra Vista, Arizona]], and treated with antivenom, but died of "complications associated with the bite".<ref>{{cite news |title=Snake bite kills Sierra Vista man |date=August 20, 2002 |publisher=Tucson Citizen |url=http://tucsoncitizen.com/morgue2/2002/08/20/46562-snake-bite-kills-sierra-vista-man/ |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> |- | Derek Lema, 2, male || September 16, 2000 || [[Eastern diamondback rattlesnake]] || Lema was bitten in the thigh by a rattlesnake while helping his father Victor Lema in their [[Lakewood Ranch, Florida]], backyard.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zucco|first1=Tom|title=Trial calls Animal Planet host|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2004/11/13/news_pf/Southpinellas/Trial_calls_Animal_Pl.shtml|accessdate=20 August 2014|work=St. Petersburg Times|date=November 13, 2004}}</ref> |}
==1990s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Anita Finch, 33, female|| Reported December 17, 1999 || [[Gaboon viper]] or [[Vipera ammodytes|hog-nosed sand viper]]|| Finch was bitten by either of these snakes she kept as pets in her [[Van Nuys, California]] home.<ref>{{cite news |title=Zoo volunteer killed by deadly snake bite|newspaper=Sacramento Bee |date=December 17, 1999 |url=http://www.igorilla.com/animal/1999/snake_bite_kills_woman.html |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> |- | John Wayne "Punkin" Brown, Jr., 34, male || October 3, 1998 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Brown was bitten while handling rattlesnake during a religious service in [[Macedonia, Alabama]]. He had reportedly survived 22 previous snake bites. Brown's wife, Melinda, had been killed by a snake during a religious service three years earlier, in August 1995. The Browns left five children orphaned. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/110404337/|title=Snake Kills Worshiper Three Years After One Killed His Wife |work=Courier Journal |location=Louisville, Kentucky |page=7 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1998-10-06 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- | Daril Ray Collins, 23, male || December 14, 1997 || Probably rattlesnake || Collins was bitten during a religious service in the community of Arjay, Bell County, Kentucky.<ref>"Man dies after being bitten while handling snake during Bell County church service". ''Lexington Herald-Leader''. July 28, 2015.</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Morrow |first=Jimmy|title=Handling Serpents: Pastor Jimmy Morrow's Narrative History of His Appalachian Jesus' Name Tradition|location=Macon, Georgia |publisher=Mercer University Press |isbn=0-86554-848X |date=2005 |page=122}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/corbin-times-tribune-dec-16-1997-p-1/|title=Knox man dies from snake bite during religious ceremony in Bell |work=Corbin Times Tribune |location=Corbin, Kentucky |page=1 |publisher=Newspaperarchive.com |date=1997-12-16 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- | Dewey Bruce Hale, 40, male || January 15, 1995 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Hale was bitten on the hand while removing a rattlesnake from a box during a religious service in [[Enigma, Georgia]]. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/152862590/|title=Man Takes Bible Verse Literally, Gets Fatal Snake Bite in Church |work=Akron Beacon Journal |location=Akron, Ohio |page=11 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1995-01-19 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- |Melinda Brown, 28, female |August 8, 1995 |[[Rattlesnake]] |Brown was bitten while handling a snake during a religious service in [[Middlesboro, Kentucky]] on August 6, 1995. She died two days later. Brown's husband, Dewey "Punkin" Brown, was killed by snake during a religious service in 1998. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113194307|title=Worshipers Faith Led to Fatal Snake Bite||date=2014-02-17|website=The Tennessean|language=en|access-date=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- | Kale Saylor, 77, male || March 8, 1995 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Saylor, a Pentecostal preacher, was bitten while handling a rattlesnake during a religious service in [[Bell County, Kentucky]]. Saylor figured prominently in David Kimbrough's 2002 book, ''Taking Up Serpents: Snake Handlers of Eastern Kentucky'' <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/110558561/|title=State Police Probe Death of Snake-bit Preacher |work=The Courier Journal |location=Louisville, Kentucky |page=4 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1995-03-10 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- |Brian Leslie West, 25, male || May 29, 1992 || [[Indian cobra]] ||Mr. West, who resided in [[Emmitsburg, Maryland]], had a state permit to keep more than two dozen snakes. He was tending an Indian Cobra in his basement when the snake bit him on the foot. Five minutes later he went into cardiac arrest and never awoke. He was pronounced dead an hour later at Frederick Memorial Hospital.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-05-29/news/1992150200_1_visionary-art-japanese-oyster-pet-cobra |title=Pet Cobra Bites, Kills Man |work=The Baltimore Sun |location=Baltimore, Maryland | date=1992-05-29 |accessdate=2018-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last=James | first=Michael | url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-05-30/news/1992151001_1_indian-cobra-venomous-snakes-brian-west |title=Maryland Snake Collector Dies After Being Bitten by Indian Cobra |work=The Baltimore Sun |location=Baltimore, Maryland | date=1992-05-30 |accessdate=2018-09-13}}</ref> |}
==1980s == {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Adult male || 1980s || [[Rattlesnake]] || A single fatal rattlesnake bite was reported in Utah during this decade. |- | Curtis Davison, 22, male || August 19, 1989 || [[Eastern diamondback rattlesnake]] || Davison was bitten on the top of his right hand as he transferred a six-foot rattlesnake from one cage to another at Silver Springs Nature Park near Ocala, Florida.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1989-08-28/business/8908283026_1_davison-park-officials-eastern-diamondback-rattlesnake|title=22-year-old snake handler has died in the first...|work=The Orlando Sentinel|date=August 28, 1989|author= Vicki Vaughan |accessdate=13 November 2015}}</ref> |- | Glenn R. Alexander, 29, male || March 25, 1987 ||[[Rattlesnake]] || Alexander was bitten during the 23rd Annual Brownwood Rattlesnake Roundup in [[Brownwood, Texas]] on March 21, 1987 and died four days later.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/11086515/ |title=Snakebite Fatal for Irving Man |work=The Times |location=Shreveport, Louisiana |page=7 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1987-03-26|accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> |- | Mack Ray Wolford, 39, male || August 28, 1983 || [[Timber rattlesnake]] || Wolford was bitten on the arm by a timber rattlesnake during religious services at the Lord Jesus Temple in Mile Branch, near [[Iaeger, West Virginia]].<ref name="BDT"/> Wolford did not initially seek medical treatment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Snake Bite Proves Fatal|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2523764/snake_bite_proves_fatal/|work=Daily Sitka Sentinel|location=Sitka, Alaska|date=31 Aug 1983|page=7|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> An ambulance was summoned eight hours after Wolford had been bitten, but he died during transport to Stevens Clinic in [[Welch, West Virginia]].<ref name="BDT"/> Wolford's son, Mark Wolford, died in 2012 under similar circumstances.<ref name="WPAP"/> |- | John Holbrook, 38, male || August 1982 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Reverend Holbrook was bitten while handling a rattlesnake during religious services in [[Oceana, West Virginia]].<ref name="BDT"/><ref name="Mathews">{{cite news |title='Praise-the-Lord-and-pass-the-snake' service is a trip, if you can handle it |author=Mathews, Garret |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/638481842.html?dids=638481842:638481842&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Apr+03%2C+1983&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc='Praise-the-Lord-and-pass-the-snake'+service+is+a+trip%2C+if+you+can+handle+it&pqatl=google |newspaper=The Chicago Tribune |date=April 3, 1983 |page=J3 |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> Holbrook reportedly refused medical assistance because his religion did not permit it.<ref name="BDT"/><ref name="Mathews"/> |}
==1970s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Gregory Lee Hall, 3, male || May 31, 1976 || [[Agkistrodon contortrix|Copperhead]] || Bitten on the right hand by a copperhead he picked while playing near his home in [[Jacksonville, Alabama]] on May 31, 1976.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/271548480/|title=Snakebite Fatal for Alabama Tot |work=Pensacola News |location=Pensacola, Florida |page=2 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1976-07-03 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Curtis Mounts, 61, male || May 19, 1974 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Mounts was bitten on the right arm while handling a snake during a religious service in [[Bens Run, West Virginia]] on May 16, 1974. He died three days later.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/310760733/|title=Worship Service Snakebite Fatal |work=Springfield News-Leader |location=Springfield, Missouri |page=6 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1976-05-21 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- | Richard Lee Williams, 33, male || April 2, 1974 || [[Eastern Diamondback Rattlesnake]] || Rev. Williams, of Columbus, Ohio, was bitten while handling a snake during a religious service in [[Switzer, West Virginia]] on April 4, 1974.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/100946382/|title=Snakebite Fatal |work=The Cincinnati Enquirer |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |page=14 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1974-04-05 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Gordon D. Ball, 34, male || August 5, 1973 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Ball was presumably bitten by a snake, possibly a [[Sistrurus catenatus|massasauga]], while traveling alone through [[Bergen-Byron Swamp]] on a "picture-taking expedition".<ref name="TDNO">{{cite news |title=Hidden History: Snake bite kills man in Bergen swamp, 1973 |author=Graczyk, Mark |url=http://thedailynewsonline.com/blogs/article_d33cff7c-4b59-11e1-a631-001871e3ce6c.html |newspaper=The Daily News Online |location=Batavia, New York |date=February 5, 2012 |accessdate=12 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209084938/http://thedailynewsonline.com/blogs/article_d33cff7c-4b59-11e1-a631-001871e3ce6c.html |archivedate=9 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}<!-- survey required to read article --></ref> A five-day police search recovered Ball's body from a small clearing "near Warboys Road, on the swamp's northern perimeter."<ref name="TDNO"/> An autopsy report listed snakebite as the presumptive cause of death.<ref name="TDNO"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Coroner Says Snake Bite Fatal|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/2523715/coroner_says_snake_bite_fatal/|work=The Times Record|location=Troy, New York|date=13 Aug 1973|page=7|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> |- | Beulah Bucklen, 59, female || September 24, 1972 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bucklen, of Charleston, West Virginia, was bitten while handling a snake during a religious service in [[Fraziers Bottom, West Virginia]] on September 16, 1972. She died eight days later.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/90477752/|title=Snakebite Fatal |work=Rushville Republican |location=Rushville, Indiana |page=8 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1972-09-25 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- | Susan Mary Gaboury, 34, fermale || September 13, 1972 || Probably a [[Eastern Diamondback Rattlesnake]] || While driving near [[St. Augustine, Florida]], Gaboury had stopped to relieve herself in the bushes beside the road. Thinking she had been pricked by a spiny plant, possibly the [[Spanish bayonet]], she went to the emergency room, where she was treated for an allergic reaction and released. She returned home and was found dead the next morning. A snake expert determined from the size of the bite that Gaboury had likely been bitten by a diamondback rattler.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/327244712/|title=Snakebite Fatal to Teacher After Wrong Diagnosis |work=The Tampa Timeas |location=Tampa, Florida |page=12 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1972-09-14 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Bryan L. Bristow, 28, male || December 29, 1971 || [[Cottonmouth]] || Bristow had been collecting snakes in a bag when he was bitten on the hand by a cottonmouth moccasin in [[Garyville, Louisiana]], on December 29, 1971.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/248003580/|title=Snakebite Fatal to Ohio Man |work=Palladium-Item |location=Richmond, Indiana |page=15 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1971-12-31 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |}
==1960s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | James Saylor, 24, male || February 20, 1967 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten while handling a rattlesnake during a religious service in [[Covington, Kentucky]], on February 19, 1967. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/381659171/|title=Snakebite Fatal |work=The Messenger-Inquirer |location= Owensboro, Kentucky |page=14 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1967-02-21 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Wesley Howard Dickinson, 45, male || July 10, 1966 || [[King cobra]] || An experienced herpetologist, Dickinson was bitten while force-feeding an 8-foot Indian king cobra in [[Santa Ana, California]], on July 10, 1966. Dickinson had previously survived bites from other cobras, rattlesnakes, a water moccasin and a Gila monster. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/152634600/|title=Snakebite Fatal |work=The Akron Beacon-Journal |location= Akron, Ohio |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1966-07-11 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | [[Frederick A. Shannon]], 43, male || August 31, 1965 || [[Mojave rattlesnake]] || Bitten on a finger of his left hand by Mojave rattlesnake while collecting specimens near [[Klondyke, Arizona]], on August 29, 1965. Shannon was one of the foremost American herpetologists, a physician and an expert on snakebite, having coauthored a manual for the U.S. armed services. He died on August 31, 1965, after being airlifted to a hospital in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/23468090/|title=Rattlesnake Strike Fatal to State Snakebite Expert |work=Tucson Daily Citizen |location=Tucson, Arizona |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1965-08-31 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Donald Bebis, 1, male || August 4, 1965 || [[Rattlesnake]] || 15-month-old Don Bebis was playing in the yard at his home in [[Cat Creek, Montana]], when he was bitten on both legs on August 4, 1965.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/21518614/|title=Snakebites Fatal to Infant |work=The Daily Inter Lake |location=Kalispel, Montana |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1965-08-05 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref>
|- | Jerry de Bary, 37, male || January 27, 1964 || [[Bitis arietans | African puff adder]] ||De Bary, the director of the Salt Lake City Zoo, was bitten on the left forearm by a South African puff adder when he opened the cage to tend to the animal.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/109040058/|title=Snakebite Fatal to Zoo Director |work=The Courier-Journal |location=Louisville, Kentucky |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1964-01-28 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Columbia Gay Hagerman, 22, female || September 28, 1961 || Timber rattlesnake || Hagerman was bitten on the right thumb during her first snake handling at a church service in [[Jolo, West Virginia]]. She declined medical assistance and died at her parents' home. Her parents had previously been bitten several times by copperheads and rattlesnakes, recovering each time without seeking treatment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/85693400|title=Columbia Gay Chafin Hagerman (1938 - 1961) - Find A Grave Memorial}}</ref> |- | Jimmy Cornell, 14, male || March 15, 1961 || [[Eastern diamondback rattlesnake]] || Bitten on the hand by diamondback rattler while reaching into a gopher hole in [[Fort Myers, Florida]], on March 11, 1961. He died four days later.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/69626267/|title=Snakebite Fatal |work=The Tribune |location=Great Bend, Kansas |page=9 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1961-03-16 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |}
==1950s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | David P. Henson, 74, male || July 26, 1959 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Rev. Henson, described as an "elderly minister" in the Free Holiness Church, was bitten on the hand while handling a rattlesnake during a religious service in [[Robinwood, Alabama]]. Relatives report that he had been handling snakes for "more than 30 years" and that he had survived several bites during that time.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/394953402 |title=Snakebite Fatal to Southern Cleric |work=Wilkes-Barre Times Leader|location=Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania |page=16 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1959-07-27 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- | [[Karl P. Schmidt]], 67, male || September 26, 1957 || [[Boomslang]] || Schmidt, a renowned herpetologist, died in [[Chicago]] while documenting the effects of a venomous bite of a snake he was trying to identify. The snake was later identified as a juvenile African Boomslang.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pri.org/stories/2015-11-10/he-documented-his-own-death-snakebite-instead-going-hospital|title=He documented his own death by snakebite instead of going to the hospital|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref> |- | Anna Marie Yost, 46, female || August 29, 1955 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten on the arm while handling a rattlesnake during a religious service in [[Savannah, Tennessee]] on August 29, 1955. Her brother, Mansel Covington, a well-known snake handler, was bitten on both hands during the same service but survived. The event is recounted in writer [[Dennis Covington | Dennis Covington's]] 1995 book, [[Salvation on Sand Mountain]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/83955609 |title= Religious Snakebite Fatal to Woman |work=Rushville Republican|location=Rushville, Indiana |page=8 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1955-08-31 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | [[George Went Hensley]], 74, male || July 25, 1955 || Unknown || Hensley died from a bite sustained while [[Snake handling|handling snakes]] during a religious service in Florida. |- | Frieda Hoxter, 25, female || March 6, 1955 || Cobra || A German immigrant to the U.S., performing as "Princess Naja" at a night club in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], was bitten by one of two cobras she used in her performance. She died at St. Joseph's Hospital, where she had been hospitalized previously for earlier snakebites.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19550307&id=3wwrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jJoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5233,2641755 |title= German Dancer Dies of Cobra Bite |work=Reading Eagle|location=Reading, Pennsylvania |page=7 |publisher=Google News Archive |date=1955-03-07|accessdate=2018-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Snake Dancer Dies of Cobra's Bite |work=The Post Standard|location=Syracuse, New York |page=1 |date=1955-03-07}}</ref> |- | Karen Perry, 1, female || June 26, 1953 || [[Rattlesnake]] || 15-month-old Perry was playing in the backyard of her home in [[Tujunga, California]] when she was bitten on the hand by a "pencil thin", 18-inch long rattlesnake. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/386190188 |title=Rattler's Bite Fatal to Girl 15 Months Old |work=The Los Angeles Times |location=Los Angeles, California |page=29 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1953-06-26 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |- | Nathaniel Akins, 25, male || August 18, 1951 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten by a "giant rattlesnake" while cutting pulpwood alongside the Orlando Highway in [[Kissimmee, Florida]] on Augusta 18, 1951.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/326819027|title=Snakebite Fatal to Kissimmee Negro |work=Tampa Tribune |location=Tampa, Florida |page=10 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1951-08-19 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Ruthie Craig, 50, female || July 15, 1951 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten on the right forearm while handling a rattlesnake during a religious service in [[New Hope, Alabama]] on July 15, 1951.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/279943546 |title=Snakebite Fatal at Faith Sect Rites |work=Elmire Advertiser|location=Elmira, New York |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1951-07-17 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |}
==1940s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Ben Padgett, 26, male || September 2, 1949 ||[[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten below the left knee while cutting trees near [[Maxville, Florida]] on September 2, 1949<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/327634558/ |title=Snakebite Fatal |work=Tampa Tribune |location=Tampa, Florida |page=4 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1949-09-03|accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | [[Grace Olive Wiley]], 64, female || July 20, 1948 ||[[Indian cobra]] || Wiley, an experienced herpetologist, who was known as the "Queen of the Cobras" for her work in the movie industry, was posing for a photograph with a juvenile cobra when she was bitten after a flashbulb startled the snake. [[Cypress, California]] <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/74915633/ |title=Grace Wiley Killed by Cobra |work=Long Beach Independent |location=Long Beach, California |page=1 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1948-07-21|accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Mrs. Floyd Butterbaugh, 22, Female || July 18, 1947 || Timber rattlesnake || Mrs. Butterbaugh was bitten by a timber rattler at her home on Piney Creek, 12 miles east of Chillicothe, Ohio near the Tar Hollow State Forest. She was picking beans in her garden when she was bitten. She died the next day. This is the last known fatality from a wild snake bite in the state of Ohio.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/60409667/ |title=Dies Of Snake Bite |work=The Evening Review |location=East Liverpool, Ohio |page=6 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1947-07-19 |accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> |- | Jerry Frier, 7, male || June 22, 1943 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Frier died from rattlesnake bite in [[Lafayette County, Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://burval.net/p739.htm|title=Burval Genealogy - Person Page|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref> |- | Dorothy Louise Key, 8, female || May 1, 1942 ||[[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten while walking in woods near her home in [[Bradenton, Florida]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/352827575/ |title=Dies Of Snake Bite |work=Pensacola News Journal |location=Pensacola, Florida |page=4 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1942-05-02|accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> |- | Mahel Coffey, 10, female || July 21, 1941 ||[[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten by a rattlesnake while picking berries near her home in [[Lenoir, North Carolina]] <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/10900694/ |title=Snakebite Fatal |work=The High Point Enterprise |location=High Point, North Carolina |page=7 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1941-07-21|accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> |- | John Charles Goss, 2, male || June 23, 1941 ||[[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten beneath the right knee while at a picnic near the city reservoir alongside the Willow Creek Highway in [[Bradford, Pennsylvania]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/11086515/ |title=Snakebite Fatal to Bradford Boy |work=The Record-Argus |location=Greenville, Pennsylvania |page=1 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1941-06-24|accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> |- | Reba Ann Cooper, 2, female || April 28, 1940 || [[Rattlesnake]] || The daughter of a rancher, Cooper was bitten by a rattlesnake on a ranch near [[Rocksprings, Texas]]. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/366696905/|title=Snake Bite Fatal to Texas Child, 2 |work=Austin American-Statesman |location=Austin, Texas |page=7 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1940-04-29 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |}
==1930s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Paul D. Emerson, 50, male || September 17, 1937 || unknown || Dr. Emerson, a nationally known soil expert, was found dead on a trail eight miles west of [[Rapid City, South Dakota]]. Bitten on the left leg by a snake, Dr. Emerson had applied a tourniquet below the knee and made an incision over the wound with razor blade before he died. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/428947228/|title=Snakebite Fatal for Soil Expert |work=The Columbus Telegram |location=Columbus, Nebraska |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1937-09-21 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Marshal Ray Weddle, 5, male || July 24, 1937 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten while playing near his home in [[Riggins, Idaho]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/281146645/|title=Rattle Snake Bite Fatal to Boy, 5 |work=The Daily Herald |location=Provo, Utah |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1937-07-28 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | B.T. Walley, 34, male || July 21, 1937 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten while walking near [[Laurel, Mississippi]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/33931822/|title=Rattle Snake Bite Fatal to Laurel Man |work=The Delta Democrat Times |location=Greenville, Mississippi |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1937-07-22 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Alfred Weaver, 35, male || May 4, 1936 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Weaver, a 35-year-old itinerant was bitten on the hand by a rattlesnake during a "faith" demonstration at a revival service in [[Bartow, Florida]] on May 3, 1936. He died the next day after refusing medical treatment.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/344351161/|title=Faith Snakebite Fatal |work=The Sentinel |location=Carlisle, Pennsylvania |page=5 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1936-05-05 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- | Jess Correll, 28, male || July 24, 1931 || [[Agkistrodon contortrix|Copperhead]] || A farmer, Correll was bitten on the hand, while in the hay loft of his barn near [[Washington, Indiana]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/262012586/|title=Rattle Snake Bite Fatal to Laurel Man |work=Lafayette Journal and Courier |location=Lafayette, Indiana |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1931-07-24 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |}
==1920s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Wilmer Hassinger, 15, male || June 15, 1929 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bitten while fishing along Rattling Creek near [[Lykens, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/281146645/|title=Snakebite Fatal to Wilmer Hassinger|work=The Standard |location=Lykens, Pennsylvania |page=1 |publisher=Newspapers.com |date=1929-06-21 |accessdate=2018-07-08}}</ref> |- |Maggie Collins, 33, female |May 29, 1929 |Rattlesnake |Collins died from a rattlesnake bite while picking blackberries in Grady County, Georgia. |- | Rebecca Nimmons, 19, female || July 1928 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Nimmons was killed by a rattlesnake in [[Pickens County, South Carolina]]. |- | Jane Lancaster, 66, female || August 21, 1921 || Probably a [[timber rattlesnake]] || The bite occurred in Franklin Township at Snake Hollow, near the present-day Scioto Trails State Forest, southeast of Chillicothe, Ohio, in [[Ross County, Ohio|Ross County]]. An article in the ''Chillicothe Gazette'' explained that it could not be confirmed whether the bite Lancaster suffered was from a copperhead or rattlesnake. Given the severity of her wounds, it was likely a timber rattlesnake.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/LANCASTER/2000-09/0969108177 |title=First Death from Snake Bite in Ross County Since Records Of Mortality Has Been Kept in This County |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> |}
==1910s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Gustav A. Link, 51, male || August 15, 1917 || [[Timber rattlesnake]] || Link was showing his pet timber rattlesnake to a group of [[University of Pittsburgh]] students in the taxidermy lab of [[Carnegie Museum of Natural History|Carnegie Museum]]. While putting the snake back into its cage, Link was bitten on his right index finger. Link was admitted to [[UPMC Mercy|Mercy Hospital]] and treated. Herpetologist [[Raymond Ditmars]] sent antivenom from New York by train in the custody of a Pullman porter. Antivenom was administered 12 hours after the bite, but Link died 15 hours after the bite.<ref>Daggette, Alvin S., M.D. (1917). "Report of a Case of Snake Bite, with Treatment". ''Pennsylvania Med. J.'' '''20''': 838-840.</ref><ref>[[William Jacob Holland|Holland WJ]] (1917). "Obituary of Gustav A. Link, Senior". ''Annals of Carnegie Museum'' '''11''': 5-7.</ref> |- | Helen Moomey, 4, female || September 23, 1915 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Moomey died from a rattlesnake bite she received while playing with friends near her house in [[Billings County, North Dakota]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Little Girl is Mortally Bitten by a Rattlesnake|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/nd/slope/newspapr/marmail/1913-15.txt|accessdate=20 August 2014|work=The Marmarth Mail|date=September 24, 1915|volume=VIII|number=42|via= USGENWEB ARCHIVES}}</ref> The [[prairie rattlesnake]] is the only venomous snake in North Dakota. |- | Two Wilson children || June 1913 || [[Crotalus viridis|Prairie rattlesnake]] || The children were bitten and died while their family was sleeping on the [[North Dakota]] prairie. |- | Frank Stankiewicz, 57, male || July 9, 1910 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Stankiewicz, a Lithuanian immigrant, trapped a rattlesnake while fishing near [[Nanticoke, Pennsylvania]]. When he attempted to pull off the rattles, the snake escaped and bit him twice.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/51957537/|title=Rattle Snake Bite Fatal |work=The Pittston Gazette |location=Pittston, Pennsylvania |page=1 |via=Newspapers.com |date=1910-07-11 |accessdate=2018-07-09}}</ref> |}
==1900s== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! width=100|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |- | Mary Bull, 12, female || July 9, 1907 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Bull died from a rattlesnake bite in [[Shenandoah County, Virginia]]. The timber rattlesnake is the only species of rattlesnake in this region. |- | Frank Benham, 2, male || September 25, 1903 || [[Prairie rattlesnake]] || Benham died from a rattlesnake bite in Adams County, Colorado, 17 miles north of Deer Trail. |- | Edward Comstock, 39, male|| September 25, 1900 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Comstock died as result of a bite from a rattlesnake during a snake handling exhibition on Water Street in [[Chillicothe, Ohio]]. A newspaper article read: "Edward Comstock, manager of a snake show, was bitten by a rattlesnake at Chilll- cothe, O., last week and died, in terrible agony. His hand and arm swelled to an enormous size. Every known antidote was tried without avail. He was changing the snakes and put his hand into a box, when the rattler bit him. He had handled snakes for years."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mocavo.com/Billboard-Jul-Dec-1900-Volume-12-13/338710/97 |title=Seeking Relatives |work=The Billboard |volume=12, 13 |page=97 |publisher=Mocavo.com |date=Jul–Dec 1900 |accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> |}
==Before 1900== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! width="200"|Name, age, gender!! style="width:100px;"|Date!! style="width:150px;"|Species!! style="width:550px;"|Location, comments |-
|Belinda Rourke, 6, female || June 1891 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Rourke died from a bite while playing near a pile of rocks near the family's ranch in the Purgatory River Valley of southern Colorado. The child survived for a day after the bite. |- |Rebecca O. Andrews, approximately 28, female || c. 1890 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Andrews died from a rattlesnake bite in [[Kansas]]. |- |James Ananias Brannon, 2, male || July 1882 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Brannon died from a rattlesnake bite received while lying on a blanket in [[Texas]]. |- |George Sides, 6, male || May 30, 1873 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Sides died in Texas of a rattlesnake bite. |- |Frederick Louis Niemann, male || 1873 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Niemann died in [[Saline County, Kansas]], from a rattlesnake bite. |- |William A. Perrin, male || 1859 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Perrin was killed by a rattlesnake at Stribling Springs in [[Augusta County, Virginia]]. The [[timber rattlesnake]] is the only rattlesnake in the state. |- |Maggie Lee, female |October 24, 1854 |[[Rattlesnake]] |She was the first child to die of a snakebite in Parker County, Texas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~txparker/history/firsts.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519182300/http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~txparker/history/firsts.htm|title=Parker County, Texas Firsts|archivedate=19 May 2017|publisher=USGenWeb Project|accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> |- |H. M. Pettigrew, 31, male || August 15, 1841 || [[Rattlesnake]] || Pettigrew died from a rattlesnake bite while clearing land in [[Fannin County, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Fannin Co. TX Pettigrew Cemetery N. of Windom|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/tx/fannin/cemetery/pettigrew.txt|publisher=USGENWEB ARCHIVES|accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> |- |Richardson, infant son of Wm. & Ella |1796 |[[Rattlesnake]] |Richardson Cemetery (Town of Springport, NY) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://rootsweb.ancestry.com/~nycayuga/cem/cem210.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427101948/http://rootsweb.ancestry.com/~nycayuga/cem/cem210.htm|title=Richardson Cemetery|archivedate=27 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> |- |Unknown person |1791 |[[Timber rattlesnake]] |This was the last fatal snakebite in the state of [[Massachusetts]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dfg/nhesp/species-and-conservation/nhfacts/crotalus-horridus.pdf|title=Timber Rattlesnake: Natural Heritage & Endangered Species Program|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> |- | Child, 5 or 6 || August 28, 1790 || [[Rattlesnake]] || A child was bitten by a rattlesnake, and died the next day, in [[Hardwick, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite newspaper |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= We Hear from Hardwick |url= |journal= Gazette of the United-States|location= New York, New York |publisher= |date= September 25, 1790|access-date= }}</ref>
|}
